review_title: Nice people, ancient systems and very low payment
pros:
People: 
Everyone is really kind, supportive and positive.

Hiring process:
Hiring process is very straight forward, quick and fair.

Organisation:
In general processes are clear and everything is well organised.

Office:
The office is nice, modern, comfortable and in a nice location. The cafeteria on the 16th floor is great!

Culture:
The culture is quite flexible and chilled, no micromanagement.

Clear progression path:
There's a very clear progression path, no fuss, no politics, purely based on performance.

Equipment:
You get a decent monitor (which is a good size), a used laptop (ThinkPad) that not always work smoothly, and accessories such as Lenovo mouse & keyboard and a reasonable headset. Nothing fancy but ok.

Pension and Health Insurance:
Good pension scheme and good health insurance police with BUPA.
cons:
Compensation:
The salary is very low for the amount of work you are expected to take on. In other industries I was paid almost double to do less than what is expected at the Financial Ombudsman Service. Also, as an investigator, when you get a promotion to the next stage, your salary only goes up by £2000/year and you take a lot more work. It's not motivating at all.

Hybrid work:
You are expected to be in the office 4x a month to do exactly what you do at home but with a couple more people sitting next to you. It's a completely waste of time and money on commute to be to go into the office where the collaboration is minimum.

Systems:
The system to deal with cases is absolute ancient! It's Windows 1998 vibes all over again. Slow, inefficient, manual, very few things done automatically, not intuitive, it's actually a joke for a company operating in 2023.

Benefits:
Very basic benefits compared to other companies in Finance. It doesn't even complement the low salary. Not attractive at all.

Feedback during training:
Mentors are supportive but there's a massive lack of consistency on their feedback. One day someone says it's ok to write in a way, the other day someone else says it's not ok to write in the same way. It's very confusing and unnecessarily strict with the rules for writing letters and views. It slows down the entire process and you never feel you're good enough. It's frustrating. 

Volume of work:
Investigators are expected to take on 20 cases on their first 3 months of training and write high quality views with very little experience. This unrealistic expectation causes a lot of frustration and some people just leave because the money is not even worth the stress.

review_title: Dispatches still rings true 4 years later
pros: Some good people that are trying their best in less that ideal circumstances.
cons: I spent a short time at FOS after a long career in compliance, and it has taken me months to get over what I can only describe as the trauma the “academy” left me with. First of all, I was hired with almost 10 years of experience in complaint handling, compliance, and financial products. I had everything going for me except the experience in the product I was chosen to “specialise” in. The 6 month academy starts with live cases on day 3, meaning you are introducing yourselves to unassuming consumers acting as if you are a specialist, when you have barely got your head around the language needed to discuss the technicalities of the product in question. Academy mentors are from the old FOS, and many of them worked their way up from more menial admin roles, so they have no experience in finance outside the walls of the ombudsman. Their advice is non-committal, and their feedback is often misguided. On countless occasions my gut told me this, and it would come out later our findings on the case in question hadn’t been in line with FCA regulation or our previous approach, despite seeking guidance every step of the way. They are pushing any answer out the door and hoping savvy consumers and businesses won’t object. The targets in the academy would be more than achievable with the right product based training, but without this, my entire time spent there felt like a bad dream where I had an exam on a book I hadn’t read. Myself and many others asked for more support and training, and we were assured we would receive this, or we had already had it, or we should have more faith in our decision making skills. At least 6 people left my cohort in the first 3 months. We were working evenings and weekends in our own time to try and make progress, people were crying at their desks, and still no meaningful changes were made. I had to admit that I was on the verge of a breakdown to get any sort of help, but I was so broken from this experience I just had to get out. I am a balanced person, and I was confident in my abilities when I walked through those doors. Being gaslit by my manager for months truly left me an anxious wreck, unable to see a way out. I should have looked into the findings of the Dispatches documentary before taking a job at FOS. They might have tweaked a few aspects of the role and training since 2018, but the general mismanagement, absolute negligence, and misuse of money is still at the heart of FOS. The enquiry that was conducted shortly after the documentary was not a true reflection of the service (for so many reasons that I don’t have time to go into here). I think another undercover investigation would reveal more negligence than I have words to articulate. It is rotten to the core.

pros: Great people, working to make difference
cons: limited progression opportunities working your way through organisation

pros:
Apart from the usual banal Glassdoor platitude about the people that work here (which holds true for the most part), there are a few:

* I've learned a lot about the workings of various financial products and consequently have become far savvier with all things financial in my own personal life. 

* The work can be highly rewarding. 

* I've been able to specialise in a really interesting area of casework after changes were made to the initial investigations model. 

* There are plenty of opportunities to step up and gain exposure to more senior responsibilities if you have a supportive manager. I was lucky to have had several incredible  OMs in my time at the service, though be warned that this may not be your experience if you are a prospective employee. 

* It's not a bad place to work if you're a graduate looking for some exposure to financial services or legal work.
cons:
Some cursory thoughts:

* The salary is poor across all roles. Extremely poor when compared with other similar organisations in London in particular. This has been compounded by a measly 2.5% pay-rise this year following a wholly unjustifiable pay-freeze the year before. An utter slap in the face for the hard-working staff here given the rampant inflation and wider economic climate in the UK at the moment. 

* The pay scales are unfair. For Investigators it's ludicrous, with the salary jumping up in miniscule increments between levels, despite the workload and target requirements increasing fairly drastically. The jump up from L3 to SI is significant in terms of responsibilities but the pay-rise is equally microscopic. They need to review the bandings and make adjustments as there is little reason for people to push themselves onto the next level. 

* The best people are leaving in droves and the ongoing brain-drain over the last several years has really started to tell. Anyone really good that joins the service quickly realises their error and scarpers off to pastures greener elsewhere, normally to progress their careers with more influential and prestigious organisations (the FCA being a particularly popular destination). The organisation is now reliant on a precious few highly-skilled OMs to make key decisions on policy, and these staff members are generally poorly treated and stretched to near breaking point with the plethora of other responsibilities they juggle. It's unsustainable. 

* Conversely, there's not enough attrition at the OM and OL position. There are some extremely unimpressive figures in these roles (anyone working here for a while will no doubt have a few names in mind) that have been clinging on for dear life for several years, meaning highly talented and more qualified staff in junior positions have been unable to progress upwards, causing them to look for opportunities elsewhere. I understand many SIs have already left or are heading for the exits at pace because of the lack of progression opportunities into the OM role. 

* The Investigations model has been a disaster from start to finish. It has caused untold stress and unhappiness for so many people here and made a functioning service far, far worse. 

* A new operational model is being worked on and will be released at some nebulous point in the distant future, but staff have little confidence that leadership will get this right. There has been next to no communication on what to expect from this new model, when it will actually happen, and how that will affect people's jobs. Will SIs be turned into a pack of dejected, myopic line managers? Will OMs need to apply for a new Ombudsman position? Will Investigators be given an extra 10 cases to close per quarter? Will the unfairly forgotten-about and oft-mistreated SAs become full time service complaint responders, churning out begrudging apology after begrudging apology to a litany of irked and irate consumers? Who knows? Certainly not I. 

* Staff are demotivated. People simply don't take pleasure in the job anymore and staff surveys have shown that pride in what we do has plummeted. The root cause for this is the relentless pressure and stretching of people to breaking point. Pressure to hit target numbers week in, week out, has made what could have been an interesting and meaningful job into a numbers game. We can thank PWC for this, whose impact at FOS can be likened to that scene from Glengarry Glen Ross where a risible, corporate Alec Baldwin lectures and emasculates a team of hapless salesmen about their various ineptitudes; explaining that they either achieve impossible goals or they hit the bricks. Though saying that, at least Alec Baldwin's character solicited a few chuckles, whereas nobody was laughing at the FOS as we saw our baffled, moribund CEO hauled before the TSC for a succession of scoldings at the hands of furious MPs appalled at what our Service had become. 

* The systems used are generally terrible and not fit for purpose. Phoenix, the case handling software built within an unsuitable Microsoft framework, is clunky, confusing and complicated. Clipper, the previous iteration, was vastly superior in nearly every way. PowerBI has been more effective and is a useful tool, but still has its issues (try filtering for cases by a specific operational warning for an example) and the decision to not allow data from PowerBI to be extracted onto a spreadsheet is truly maddening. 

* I could honestly keep rabbiting on. I haven't even talked about the huge queues, the unworkable and unrealistic service standards, the phone shift scandal, the failures of senior leadership, the poor training, the unfair treatment of staff in the ASA, the lack of R and R for those that routinely go above and beyond etc etc. but I'll stop here as you're probably as bored of reading this review as I have been living the reality.

review_title: A restructure by any other name is still a restructure
pros: The work is interesting and the outcomes of some disputes can be life changing for the complainant. The seriousness of some of the issues the organisation deals with every day cannot be understated.
cons:
I have worked at the service for many years but right now is its most challenging iteration - no mean feat when you look back over a checkered history. Being an Ombudsman Manager is a thankless task. The outside world perhaps has no idea of the scope of the role - the OM has a decision target for the cases they must resolve, they line manage Investigators that are experiencing varying degrees of burnout and disillusionment. This is often more involved than being the point of contact for one to ones etc- if there are capability or disciplinary issues, the OM is expected to lead on supporting and investigating on those matters - a full time job in and of itself. In addition to this, if a complainant raises concerns about the level of service they have received, the OM has to down tools and respond. The OM is also required to undertake quality checks and if they have a particular interest in an area of casework, they also have to find the time to keep abreast of technical developments in an ever changing financial world as well as being on hand on demand to provide support to Investigators that are struggling with cases that are ever more complex. 

It is a vast role and the level of renumeration does not fairly reflect the amount of work that is done after hours to keep afloat. It's also not a level playing field because of the amount of people that are choosing to work after hours and distorting what it is possible to achieve in regular working hours. To those people I would say no matter what you do, it's never enough. 

There has been much talk for a very long time about the organisation of the future, but it lacks any detail. It is unclear whether people will have to reapply for redesigned posts at a later stage. Communication on the issues that matter is either non existent or tone deaf. When staff raised concerns that the current pay review/banding structure is inconsistent and demotivating (there's a pay band for each level but it is impossible to progress in the pay band so you are always at the entry point no matter what) the response given was that people don't work for the service for the money. Point taken but staff used to be treated fairly and the seriousness of the decisions we were making about people's financial affairs was historically recognised by both the connection to the judicial scale and a performance related pay. The benefits package is not as competitive as they think it is. There is little to no investment in professional development for experienced staff. 

The mistakes of the last six years linger and for all the change there's been at the top, on a day to day basis nothing has actually changed for the people still doing the work - if anything, there is more pressure now very senior staff are going through cases one by one and demanding to know why they have not been resolved. There is no trust that your staff are in control and know what they are doing and there is no recognition that some cases are complex and will take longer and that's not an issue because the parties to the complaint understand that. Language used by OLs is negative and punitive - no exceptions, no excuses. There's no recognition that people that are doing their best after many years of uncertainty, putting aside a global pandemic and a cost of living crisis. Reward and recognition for team building and motivation is either conspicuous by its absence or so trite its offensive. 

I would think twice before accepting a job role in this environment. There is better out there- colleagues that have moved on to other organisations have commented on a vast improvement to their physical and mental health. I am waiting to see if my role is in scope for redundancy before making the next move- who knows, if one of the other recent posts here is anything to go by- the office will be moving to Leeds- the fact that this is the first time I've heard of that tells you all you need to know about how much staff are valued here.

pros:
Interesting and varied work. Opportunity to develop a specialist area, learning a lot about a certain financial product, although you don't always get a say in what to specialise in.

Most of the time you get a lot of autonomy in your work (exceptions listed below).

Good internal sources for learning about different financial products, and lots of support available if you are dealing with a tricky case.

Clear path for progression within the investigator role; however, it's a difficult leap from investigator to senior investigator/ombudsman. Possibility of going part time. Performance related annual bonus - from £2k if you're meeting expectations and almost £5k if you're significantly exceeding them. The starting salary for investigators is about £29k but that can go up to £45k in around 3 years if you keep exceeding the targets - but heads up, targets are hard. You can also opt to increase your targets for extra pay. Sometimes management go out of their way to recognise your work, e.g. a £500 bonus to everyone during covid, and I was once sent a big box of biscuits at Christmas.

In my experience, management were reasonable and understanding, but many colleagues have some horror stories about cruel managers. That said, HR must be doing something right because the vast majority of investigators are great people, always lovely to work with, and more experienced investigators routinely go out of their way to help you in spite of their own workload. I think many of the Ombudsman Managers (your direct manager, if you're an investigator) are also great, but the further up the management ladder you go, the more purely rotten people you find. Personally, I always attributed difficulties with OMs to the pressure they're under from senior management.
cons:
There is a strong focus on targets, so the workload can be challenging, but targets don't take into account that some cases require much more work than others. You will eventually adjust to strategically planning your caseload to meet each quarter's targets, but that shouldn't be necessary in the first place. You will end up working longer than you are paid for to meet targets.

The customer service standards are largely performative, and show that management don't trust investigators to use their initiative. There is a strong focus on making phone calls (especially when delivering an outcome on a case) as much as possible. I've had many cases where this just didn't make sense, for example, if you're dealing with a particularly complex case, it might be best to send your findings in writing first and ask the consumer to give you a call once they've read your report - yet doing this has lost me points in customer service checks, as we are supposed to call first and then send our findings. It's like investigators are punished for not acting like cogs in a machine. Additionally, a lot of the phone calls are tricky - even when you're giving a consumer the answer they want, they often find something to be upset about. I've had some downright abusive calls (although you're never expected to take abuse), and sometimes it's depressing when you feel like, despite all your hard work, you just can't please anyone - this is a feeling you will sadly have to get used to.

There was talk of this changing, but when I was there (a year ago), all investigators had to answer the general helpline for approx 3 hours a week. On phone shifts, there are many queries that you won't be qualified to answer and many more that could easily be dealt with by a dedicated customer service team. Since each investigator develops a specialist area, this seems like a waste of each investigator's expertise. There are many ways that phone shifts could be organised more efficiently to take advantage of each staff member's specialist knowledge; eg. I could answer many questions about certain types of insurance, but I know very little about credit agreements. On that note, although everyone has a specialist area, investigators are still expected to take on a few more general basic cases - personally I would prefer if all cases were delegated to whomever can deal with them best. If a banking specialist has to deal with a basic insurance case, and an insurance specialist has to deal with a basic banking case, why not let them swap?

Finally, I think many potential employees are enticed by the job title "investigator," thinking it will open a lot of doors later on. It's certainly an interesting job, but in my experience, quite a number of future employers just see it as a complaint handling job - not to mention that many financial institutions don't exactly love the FOS (although I imagine some see it as advantageous to have a former FOS employee on board). Don't get me wrong, you'll learn a lot in the job and it helped me break into the legal profession, but the job primarily qualifies you to do customer relations/ complaints jobs - not finance jobs. If you're early in your career/a graduate/a customer service professional, the investigator job could be great, but if you're more experienced, I don't think it's going to serve as a stepping stone into investment banking or anything like that. Many investigators move on to work at the FCA, and an impressive number go on to consulting work (eg PwC). I suppose it comes down to how you portray the job on your CV - there are many aspects to it, so it can be pretty versatile and applicable to a lot of other jobs.

review_title: Poor pay for the city and a dilute role with a lack of focus
pros:
Working at the Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS) gave me both great insight into the spectacular ways financial products can go wrong, how petty the general public can be and how to manage such insights in such a mediocre way from an organisational stand point, that it doesn’t matter if the investigators and ombudsman are exceptional at their job the process can get in the way.
 FOS exists to informally resolve complaints about financial products as an alternative to the courts. 
As an investigator, your role is to make complaint resolution cheaper for the FOS as investigators cost half as much as an ombudsman in salary. You handle all the chaff and anyone who disagrees with your answer gets their case referred to an ombudsman (in about 3 to 9 months time).
What’s good about the role
•	35 hour work week
•	Nice office (However it’s a bit too loud a times due to being open plan)
•	25 days annual leave, 8 bank holidays and unofficial bonus day at Christmas
•	OT for investigators was £250 a case and for Ombudsman it was £100.
cons:
What’s bad about the role?
The issue with the investigator job is that the FOS doesn’t seem to know what they want them to be good at. The core of the investigator role is to assess evidence (usually in the form of testimony and financial documents) from complainants and financial businesses and determine if a financial business has correctly applied its terms and conditions and done it in a fair way. Then write a report on this matter and communicate it to both parties, then if either party disagrees with what you have to say (after trying to convince them you’re right) the complaint will then be referred to an ombudsman (3-9 month wait).
However due to some questionable business decision upper management seems to be determined to dilute this role as much as possible. Examples include the following.
Having investigators man the phone lines for at least three hours a week. 
Originally this was envisioned as a way for investigators to organically pick up new complaints. In reality this hardly ever happened because not every call is a new complaint (most weren’t). And a lot of the complaints that did come in could only be worked by specific departments.
So for three hours a week (more like four or five if you include prep time before the calls, and any phone call that goes past your specific hour) you are acting as a customer service agent rather than an investigator not picking up new cases and not progressing current cases.
While working a case Internal service standards ask you update complainants every two weeks.
This seems fine theory but in reality when you’re juggling between 30 and 80 cases that’s a lot of admin for not a lot of gain (the update is generally just to assure them we haven’t forgotten about their complaint with no meaningful update content) . This also creates a death spiral of work where the more cases you have the more time you need to spend updating the complainants which means you have less time for work. Five minutes times thirty is two and a half hours every two weeks keeping the minimum case load of people updated. It’s important to let people know what going on but this particular method seems like a waste of time. I’d personally increase this working standard to a minimum of four weeks (but ideally six).
After the case has been referred to an ombudsman you’re still responsible for its admin(So now you’re also a secretary)
After either side has asked for an ombudsman to review the case the investigator is still responsible for the day to day admin on the complaint. At this point I have nothing more meaningful to add to the case yet I’m still required to handle calls and emails for the complainant. When an ombudsman wants to ask a question to either side they don’t email them directly (I have no idea why) but instead write a draft email and ask that I send it from my account. I just don’t understand why they don’t have a business admin department to do this instead.
Additional issues
Poor focus on what they want an investigator to do with a number of tasks being required that don’t contribute to their performance target.
Poor IT systems – They use an altered version of Powered BI. Which clunky email integration and poor case management systems.
Some archaic HR policies – They use the Bradford factor for sick leave which is fairly regressive. You can’t just email that you’re sick you need to call in for some unspecified reason and then management will ask you about symptoms ect.
Fairly anti union – The FOS as its own internal ICC council which is prefers to use to handle workforce matters. This to me seems like an attempt to circumvent any force a union might exert on the organisation. 
I spoke to the Unite union rep once and asked how things worked when they what to deal with union issues. E.g if you need to speak to an employee who has a union issue between (let’s just say) 4pm and 5pm does she get this time back. She explained that places with good union relationships generally give this time back in accrued annual leave. So if over a month you spend three and a half hours handling union issues work would give you a half day off. However FOS doesn’t do this which I think shows how weak union power is there.
Poor pay
Starting investigator salary is £28,600. This really isn’t enough to live off in London. Certainly not to live on your own.
Needless pay freeze
And last year (April 2021) they announced a pay freeze – Not because organisation couldn’t afford it (They had a record number of complaints in the system) but because (In their words) they needed to seem financially frugal when the economy was going through hard times).
This was despite the fact they have everyone a £500 bonus work WFH during the pandemic.
This is important to understand as they effectively traded a permanent salary increase what would have compounded year on year with a one off bonus. This roughly equates to a minimum level investigator being £10,000 less well off over the course of ten years, £15,000 for a senior investigators and £20,000 for a new to role ombudsman.
Having to work at a roles level (without corresponding pay) to get that promotion 
Being promoted to the next level of investigator requires you to have been working at that investigator level for at least three months. But realistically this could be a lot more than this as it’s possible to meet most of the requirements and then be denied a promotion due to a minor issue.
In conclusion there’s a narrow range if circumstances where I’d say working as an investigator could be recommended.

You already have a foot hold in the city and your partner earns significantly more.
Otherwise there are better city jobs than this.

review_title: Due Diligence Required – organisation in transition
pros: There is potentially rewarding work to be done, subject to individual abilities, temperament and being matched with a congenial team and product areas you can relate to. While salaries are far from stellar, the employee benefits in terms of private medical cover and the pension scheme could be an attraction. A new and dynamic Chief Ombudsman with an impressive career history of managing change appears to be rising to the challenge of improving efficiencies after a period when the organisation lost its way - losing the confidence of both consumers and businesses through huge case backlogs, suffering substantial outflows of staff and a loss of morale for many of those who remained.
cons:
For prospective applicants, checking documents and problem solving will be part of your job so you might wish to start by looking at the Independent Review from Oaklin Consulting published in December 2021 which can be found on the FOS website. Its findings - which identified significant shortcomings - were no more than observations made by past and current employees on Glassdoor (minus emotional venting) and its recommendations broadly in line with what experienced adjudicators and ombudsman could have come up with. But it will take time for the Chief Ombudsman (hopefully supported by competent management) to turn around the tanker. 
New joiners could be casualties or beneficiaries of the transition. The FOS has in the past served as a feeder organisation with some employees moving on to positions in financial firms or with the regulator (the FCA). This nonetheless remains a gamble. From the details of the current investigator profile, I would suggest that it is something bank branch staff and customer services representatives could consider (proven resilience of coping with pushback from customers should serve you in good stead). But I’m dubious that this is a worthwhile bet for academic highfliers or the legally qualified. With the huge amount of purely clerical/administrative work involved, there’s the danger of seriously punching below your weight before (after a long detour) having to get onto a professional track elsewhere.

The IT department has become rather top-heavy with senior managers whose only purpose seems to be to fill their calendars with unnecessary or pointless meetings where the real value would be more to be to deploy more resources at ground-zero.

With the impending datacentre cloud migration scheduled later this year and a 22M managed service contract being tendered, you'd be a fool to bet against the axe coming out again in the not too distant future.  

Lots of money is being spent on cloud migrations and utilising resources on demand as opposed to maintaining a significant permanent headcount, yet at the same time you can't help but notice that the existing technology staff aren't being supported or directed effectively. pros:
The benefits package - including private medical insurance, a good pension scheme, and 25 days of paid holiday plus public holidays.

The on-site facilities are really good, with a free gym, two decent canteens, and modern offices.

The underlying ethos of the Financial Ombudsman Service - putting fairness at the heart of the work they do there, and putting things right where they've gone wrong - makes it a place where you can really make a difference to people's lives and serve a valuable purpose in society.
cons:
The Financial Ombudsman Service has undergone drastic, ill-advised changes in the past few years to the way the complaints are handled. This has led to a "new way of working" which means that closing complaints is treated more like hitting sales targets, rather than case handlers taking the time necessary to understand consumers' complaints and reaching fair outcomes. Many of the appointments to the "new roles" under the "investigation" model seem to have been given to people who are lacking in genuine critical thinking skills and lacking in technical expertise (or the aptitude to learn the necessary expertise), but are instead the sort of people who can talk well without knowing what they're talking about and, in some cases, can't even write competently. Consequently, the environment has become more like a sales arena, rather than a professional dispute resolution service - where poor quality investigative work is overlooked in favour of people meeting or exceeding their productivity targets.

Furthermore, the "investigation" model is financially unsustainable - costing more per case than the "old" way of working. Many cases are also taking longer, on average, to be completed than prior to the changes. This means that the new model is failing on its fundamental objectives.

There are elements of poor management - both at middle-management level and senior-management level. Whilst the Financial Ombudsman Service proclaims to encourage openness and honesty, the culture is somewhat to suppress dissenting voices and discourage people from speaking up. Fundamental changes need to be made to the way the organisation views its employees - and this needs to be directed from the executive team, fed through to its very large HR department, and down through the senior management and middle managers. If fairness is to be at the heart of what the Financial Ombudsman Service does, this needs to apply to how its leaders and managers treat its staff.

review_title: This is the worst place I’ve ever worked!
pros: Good benefits including pension and dental.
cons:
I’ve had several jobs in admin and finance and this is absolutely the worst one! The targets are impossibly hard to meet, and if in any way you are struggling in your personal life with either family or health issues there is an extremely slim chance that your manager will care and/or offer advice. 

During my time here several people have left due to the unwilling nature of the higher up’s to change expectations of what can and can’t be done in a short space of time. Furthermore, they say they offer flexible working. This is a complete lie! If you’re working from home, they’ll monitor your activity and if for some reason you’re away for more than 15 minutes, you’re manager will call you and ask why. I feel like I’m constantly being watched. 

I know people who fell ill, especially after they caught covid and had to deal with the long-term consequences of it without having any understanding from their managers about why they need days off or frequent breaks. A lot of people are frightened of what might happen if they don’t meet targets/show up to work even when they’re ill! There was even an incidence where one of my colleagues was recovering from surgery feeling compelled to meet targets or risk losing his job.

During lockdown I told HR and my managers that I had look after my daughter alongside work so am unable to do phone shifts. They were completely unsympathetic about it and failed to arrange alternatives. 

Trainees are given complex cases a month in and are told to just “work them”. And much like those who have been here for several years, if you’re a trainee and for some reason are not catching up to others and/or struggling with caseload your manager will scold you and put you on a “plan”. This is essentially to scare you into working longer, unpaid hours until you meet their targets. I feel especially sorry for those who were tricked into joining the service on the basis that the job was advertised as investigating financial claims etc. This is nothing but a call centre job. Also, there are barely any opportunities for progression, and those who do make to managerial position seem to be the most imbecilic people you’ve met in your life. They’ve clearly never looked outside of this job or themselves.

Save your mental health and find something else! I’ve worked at plenty companies and organisations to know that it doesn’t have to be like this. It never has to be like this.

I’m not convinced that some of these 5 star reviews are genuine!

review_title: CEO is running a great organisation into the ground.
pros:
I love it here. Here are a few of the reasons why this is a great place:
* Excellent work / life balance.
* Lovely colleagues make a very nice atmosphere to work in.
* We do important work, help people and have the opportunity to make a difference.
* Often stimulating and challenging work.
* Great location (near Canary Wharf).
* Great office building.
* Subsidised canteen.
* Great benefits, including BUPA health coverage.
* Good pension scheme.
It's just such a terrible shame about all the stuff I've had to write about below. This used to be my dream job.
cons:
* Massively ill-conceived and poorly-implemented restructuring of the organisation.
* Total disdain for financial and technical knowledge, expertise and experience.
* New business model in which everyone is expected to be a "jack of all trades and master of none."
* Micro-managing of investigators, instead of trusting them to do their jobs like adults.
* Low morale as a result of all the above.
* Exclusively white and male executive team (apart from the CEO, who has surrounded herself with yes-men) who refuse to listen to feedback from their staff. Consequently the only way people can say what they think is here, on Glass Door. That's no way to run an organisation.

The problem is that, in order to save money (somehow), we are replacing the old system in which people specialised in certain areas -- pensions, investments, mortgages, banking and consumer credit, insurance etc -- with a new system of "multi-skilling" in which no-one is expected (or realistically able) to know much about anything, and will have to deal with every single kind of complaint about any kind of product. This totally devalues specialist knowledge. Yes, we make decisions which are "fair and reasonable," but we also still have to have regard for relevant laws and regulations as well, and there are too many of those for someone to know them all.

This new way of working was piloted, but then was rolled out Service-wide before even waiting for the pilot to finish! That proves the trials were a sham all along -- they were always going to force this through no matter what.

Also, the most experienced people are being driven out of the service by pay caps which are blatantly designed to force the best people out (I'm referring to grade 2 ombudsmen, the backbone of the Service -- now try to imagine an army with no sergeants). Soon there will not be enough good people to salvage the Service from this godawful mess once the Board wake up and realise the catastrophe we are hurtling towards.

We are sacrificing quality and integrity in the service we provide, and jeopardising the credibility and reputation of a once wonderful -- and still very important -- dispute resolution service which gives people the opportunity to sort out serious problems without having to go through the expense and time of litigation.

People are being forced to apply for jobs they don't want for fear of the consequences of not applying. A notable example: the new combined role of "ombudsman manager," which neither managers nor ombudsmen wanted to do. And then forcing them to micro-manage their investigators instead of letting them adopt the style of management that best suits them.

And I can't imagine that the investigators enjoy being micro-managed in such a condescending way, treating them like children. They used to be trusted, capable adults who were highly-motivated in their roles. Now they're demoralised and who can blame them?

The executive team don't want to listen to feedback. When we said "yes, we understand why change needs to happen" we did't mean that we agreed with the form the changes have taken, just that we understood that we have to save money somehow. We could break even just by increasing the PPI supplementary fee from zero to £100. But no, instead we're going to cut the best people's pay and get rid of them instead. Nice one.

Nobody feels that they can voice their dissent, except anonymously on this website. No-one feels valued. Morale has sunk low. Everyone at the coal face is unanimously of the view that this is a terrible idea, but the executive is oblivious and the Board appears not to know or care what is happening. They need to fire Caroline Wayman and all the grade 5 and 6 ombudsmen (who aren't real ombudsmen and who don't understand what the real ombudsmen, adjudicators and investigators do) and bring back Natalie Ceeney or Walter Merricks. They would sort this mess out, and would understand that someone who voices a dissenting opinion isn't a trouble-maker or a malcontent, but just a loyal employee with a love for the Service, an independent mind, and a constructive, well-intentioned alternative opinion. That used to be an asset, once.

If you're a current colleague, this may be worth five minutes of your time. 

I left the service in early 2015, after a couple of years, to become a partner in my family recruitment firm. I really enjoyed my time at FOS, my manager was very supportive, I made some brilliant friends and the work was both rewarding and interesting (if you worked anywhere but PPI). 

Sure, I was aware of the usual testosterone fuelled management rubbish that happens in all large city organisations, but I didn't ever witness anything awful myself, it was just office goss, which I have to say happened regularly - I believe I was the subject of at least three 'affairs'. 

Anyway, I hold a real fondness for this organisation, I enjoyed my time here - so I am saddened to see so many scathing, negative reviews. but now I am on the other side, trying to help others get out and that's where the problem really starts.
cons:
I currently have around 125 FOS colleagues on my books, actively looking for external opportunities, with many willing to take a pay cut just to escape the 'toxic atmosphere' (not my words, but the words of a client. 

The problem I am facing, is that the once great reputation of FOS is now crumbling around the city, I am having rejection after rejection because employers hear alarm bells when they see FOS on a CV. Sometimes this is because a few people have 'exaggerated' the truth when it comes to being 'experts' or have quite frankly ridiculous titles for what is effectively a quality admin role. But mostly its because firms now associate FOS with huge wage demands, terrible attitude and limited skills/knowledge. 

I am aware that FOS went through a boom of recruitment, but this appears to have diluted the once stringent requirements to make the grade or cut the mustard, if you will. It seems the colleague uproar and bad press is well known and widespread. 

Although I didn't apply for a promotion myself, I did find some odd decisions occur with some truly gifted colleagues of mine being overlooked, with promotions often favoured towards those with no family commitments, existing friendships with leadership or willingness to flirt. It doesn't seem this has changed, but its always been a bit of an old boys club, so I am not sure what everyone expects!

review_title: The investigation model has positives but it isn’t sustainable
pros: Nice people and offices, good benefits and overall the pay isn’t bad for what is essentially a customer service adviser.
cons:
I don’t want to come across as some bitter person who should just leave the organisation. I love what we do and actually, the new world has some very good aspects. But unfortunately, I’ve experienced first hand (as an investigator) that the flaws with the new system are too big to simply ignore. 

Knowledge: the answer is in the room. It’s true that someone out there can help you. But what I think was overlooked was that it’s not sustainable for you to not be able to do many cases without asking for help. You should be able to deal with problems because you know how to. Not because someone told you the answer and you don’t know enough to question it. What’s even more insulting is that virtual teams were created to deal with the more complex areas of casework. But there’s no training. I’m part of one and I do what I can dealing with products I’ve no idea about. They go to ombudsman and it gets looked at properly. It’s a great way to ruin staff morale. 

Quality vs quantity: without sounding too big headed, I think I have adjusted well to my role and I’m very good at both quality and quantity. But it isn’t sustainable. I’m exhausted. And I’ve seen a lot of colleagues reaching that point too. Once they were positive about difficult cases and the challenges that brings. But now with a focus back on closures through overtime incentives, people just want easy cases. If you’re bringing a complex case or take up too much of an investigator’s time, any old view will do and let’s get it to an ombudsman as soon as we can. Then it isn’t my problem. That is the reality. How do you really expect someone to look at five pension or investment cases per week and close them over the phone?

Ombudsman managers: it’s a sad fact that I would no longer feel confident in bringing my own personal complaint to the ombudsman service. Not because people are horrible here, but because I’ve seen that even ombudsmen are getting things wrong. And would I really want my case looked at by one of them? No. I would pray it goes to a “real” ombudsman who actually knows the product area. I’m not trying to be negative it’s just the reality. I’ve seen it myself. Ombudsman managers think the answer is fair (but you can’t decide that without knowing what to base it on) and so try their best to close cases over the phone. Much better as they can’t get juridically reviewed that way. 

Incoming post and phone shifts: we had a few months of overtime because the incoming post was so high. Maybe this is because everyone is already busy enough and you got rid of the department who deal with post? Also phone shifts, they’re scheduled in but you end up doing further shifts through POD cover because there aren’t enough people to answer the phones. If only we had some kind of customer contact division to help with the overspill of calls. Crazy idea.

Those of us with the benefit of external experience (and there are plenty of 'lifers' here) recognise it for what it is - a place with a good work life balance and decent friendly colleagues who try hard to do the right thing. The targets are challenging but achievable and the bureaucracy frustrating but inevitable (although it depends on your manager.) The benefits are good and the pay is decent considering the number of hours we're expected to work - if you've ever gone back into the office at 4pm you get a stream of people coming the other way! And that includes very senior management......
I should add that I really don't buy the reviews that say "FOS is a negative for your CV". We are generally friendly, well trained talented people who could excel elsewhere (albeit there are a few who probably couldn't). These sort of reviews (that we are lazy, overpaid, arrogant etc) run the risk of a self-fulfilling prophecy when it's not actually the reality at all.

I'm in the minority it seems in that I think Caroline is a very decent chief ombudsman who projects the right image externally for the service and has got the ability to see this through. Where she's gone wrong is surrounding herself with (mostly) very average people in senior positions who don't have the skills or experience to run an organisation this size or implement a change on this scale. The change programme is overdue but the model chosen has developed into the wrong one. The key reason for this (and probably the key failing in the organisation) is that few are prepared to stand up and say 'this is not going to work'. And those that do are sidelined or considered trouble makers. So we get a system ported from other organisations implemented by management consultants with no experience of this sort of organisation and its values.
We've also become obsessed by cost-cutting. In the first year i was here i was amazed that money was given virtually no consideration at all. And now it seems to be the only consideration. Over the past four years a number of extremely capable ombudsman came in from external sources and our level of quality was high - we were rejecting people who got jobs (for example) as corporate counsel at GlaxoSmithKline. Now we recruit young, capable but mainly vastly inexperienced internal candidates as "entry-grade ombudsman" - and the main attraction seems to be they'll cheaper to take on as the new breed of 'ombudsman manager.' In the new world we've found the worst bit of the public-sector in downgrading experience and filling many jobs with the cheapest person who meets the grade, rather than considering who the best applicants are. Assessing things empathetically (towards both sides) but dispassionately, with a common sense hat on. Listening carefully to the evidence presented (including what people remember but can’t back up with a document because life’s not like that). Changing your mind. Accepting you don’t know sometimes. Disappointing if that’s just. Not feeling like that’s a problem, because it isn’t. Telling your manager to chill - screw timeliness targets, this one needs time. Ignoring ombudsman when they’re wrong (they’re regularly wrong - now more than ever) in order to do the right thing. Telling an ombudsman you disagree if you disagree. Harping on and on about something not right you care about until someone notices (years too late, normally). 

That’s what empowering people means. Encouraging participation in the debate, listening to what they say, and not disregarding their concerns as irrelevant, incorrect, misguided, they’re stupider than me because I’m more important so I don’t care. 

Empowering people is not two weeks crash course of ‘this is a sort of complaint dictionary. Search for whatever the complaint is about (which hopefully you’ll just know. Pensions are simple. They’re just savings accounts in a fund or something) Then do what the dictionary says.’ Or say you can’t help because ‘commercial decision’ wins the fair and reasonable chippie.  Or there’s ‘we’re not a regulator, so we can’t make a firm (sorry - business) change its systems**’. Or reject whatever thing it was with a paragraph. Bonus points for illiteracy. £200 for distress and inconvenience, maybe, because maybe that will make it go away? Wait. No. Trouble and upset. Because whereas distress and inconvenience is a recognised legal and regulatory concept an ombudsman can award due to explicit statutory authority backed up by regulatory rules, T&U is another, more revolutionary way of saying the same thing, only it isn’t the same thing, which is better. 

The ‘system’ generally favours firms. Mostly, they have cash, know-how, documents and sometimes off-putting (souls-destroying) procedures.  And firms (business - my bad...) are often less than great at accepting they’re at fault. But a jobbie of a complainant who is just a jobbie because they were born one and so remain, without substantive or indeed any basis, make real, normal, decent people wading through oft-thankless drudgery feel sad, or pointless - possibly fearful, if that jobbie is a really nasty one. And high value complaints are capable of shifting the boot firmly onto the other foot - putting businesses under, bankrupting people, messing up lives. 

It’s not easy. At all. Sometimes it is (or should be) technical, nuanced, and life-changing. Given that, punch-drunk swings at empowering people by attempting to plough them full of misplaced confidence in their judgement on matters they don’t understand is dereliction of the statutory responsibility FOS holds. It’s also hugely unfair on the individuals being encouraged to deal with things they’re not (or shouldn’t be) comfortable with, based on feeling and intuition they can’t hope to have, because often things aren’t simple, and feeling and intuition aren’t enough.  Being placed in a position where someone tells me their life savings are gone, please help, and I need to figure out what to do when I don’t even comprehend what they’ve just told me. Then I ask my ombudsman manager and they have no clue either, or they think they do but don’t. 

Perhaps I’m being unfair. Perhaps the way I think things should be done is wrong. Perhaps I’m not. Perhaps it’s not. I want to respect and believe in FOS. It is (or should be) more important than I think it knows. I don’t want to see it humiliated on TV, it’s senior management to be summoned to awkwardly circumnavigate straightforward questions which have unequivocal definite factual answers. 

I want to have faith that I can rely on FOS to help me if I ever need it. That faith is gone. Hopefully to return some day. 

**(Note: firms are obliged to take heed of ombudsman determinations when, for example, designing systems, and controls to ensure customers are treated fairly and complaints are responded to appropriately. Also, consider that while FCA rules require an adviser to ensure their recommendation is ‘suitable’, day in, day out, ombudsmen flesh out what that means on a case by case basis and publish it for the world to see. What this means is that ombudsman determinations regulate firm conduct, not through rules, but through setting expectations based on interpretation and practical application of those rules. Not a regulator. Tell a firm on the receiving end of a decision telling them they’ve been entering into insurance contracts with customers for 15 years without knowing it...) (Note further: where does it say the ombudsman can’t require a firm to make a change to its systems, if its systems should be changed because they’re not fit for purpose? DISP 3? Nope. FSMA Part XVI? May. It’s possible to quickly and informally tell a bank that the fact they keep on reporting a non-existent CCJ against a single mum fleeing domestic violence who can’t rent a property because the bank’s systems are not fit for purpose. That’s an extreme example, but there are plenty more where that came from)

There once was a young girl who found herself at the foot of a vast castle. There was excitement, hustle and bustle, mixed altogether with friendly faces that wanted to help the people outside the castle walls. For the most part, of her many years service, she loved the fact that her abilities enabled her to make a persons day just by picking up the phone. She loved the thrill of the chase and putting things right when they had been broken by a big, bad, faceless corporation. It was rewarding work and she smiled with glee at the lovely comments the customers and fellow servants paid to her.

There was a dark side to this castle though! The establishment who went out of their way keep the poor girl under the thumb and would never allow her to move up the ranks within the castle walls. She has remained a lowly servant for such a long time that she felt weary and every time she tried to scream of her heartfelt pain she was shunned and the huge iron gate to the establishment was firmly closed at all times. It mattered not how much she ached or reasoned or tried to make any sense of it. The gatekeepers would aggressively tell her she was not worthy of any recognition no matter how much she tried to show them.

After a while the girl grew very disillusioned and very demoralised by the bleak outlook for her future. For over six years she had toiled and swept the floors as a lowly servant. She huffed and puffed and fought for her life but it was now drained. Now she is a broken shell rising each morning to wash the plates and answer the door to visitors who have problems. She dreamt of a life where her efforts were recognised and instead of being shunned was greeted with praise and the gold that she so deserved after her many years of patient, dependable and loyal service.

review_title: Don't fall for the positive reviews left by "Yes boys"
pros:
Nice office
Decent gym
Flexible working (although that is highly dependent on which manager you have)
Good pension

You will meet some great people working there amongst the bad apples. There are some teams/areas which are like bubbles of brilliance in the organisation and somehow avoid the toxicity of other areas.

There are some brilliant managers there. Unfortunately most of them were gotten rid of when restructuring took place in 2016. But if you get (very, very, very) lucky to get one of the good managers, it will turn change the majority of your experience of the organisation from bad to "ok", and if you're really really lucky, good.

You can feel like you've made a real difference in people's lives when you help them with your work and that can be very rewarding.

Some people think working here looks great on your CV. In reality, it's just the same as any other job unless you want to stay in complaint-handling for the rest of your life.
cons:
Unrealistic targets unless you cut significant corners or stop caring about your stakeholders - exactly the two things an organisation like this is meant to prevent happening in complaints resolution.

Some (a lot) of team managers and department managers will only care about whether you're making them number one on performance tables so their ego gets massaging in leadership meetings. Even if you're hitting your target, or doing more than the average performance there and doing a tonne of stuff on the side, you'll be made to feel you're not doing good enough unless you're literally the top of your department. This will drain any good feeling you got from helping consumers.

Leading on from those first two points - if you're not performing to the level they want, you'll literally be told to start cutting corners by your manager just to get your closure stats to where they "should" be even if it means you start getting cases wrong. They often stick people on "Performance Plans" with added stress, without actually doing anything significant with them to improve their performance/quality at all, or any additional support whatsoever. They act like they're doing someone a favour and giving them a tonne of support just by giving them more stress to deal with, without doing anything positive.

Some team and department management are incapable of appreciating any work you do outside of your main targeted key performance indicator. But they still want all of that extra work and side projects done - just without any appreciation or reward for it.

One-to-ones and the regular performance reviews are often widely weighted about negatives you've done/haven't done, rather than positive things you've done.

Management decisions wildly vary from one manager to the next.

Some managers will hugely micro-manage you, others won't give you any support at all.

Far too many "Yes boys" (who probably account for most of the positive reviews here) who make for a toxic atmosphere and just make out that everyone else is lazy when in reality they're the ones who are most likely to cut corners in their work and create problems for the rest of us.

Bullying that they say they're against, but in reality do little about and often turn the other way when it's done by managers.

Senior management who pretend they're on your side to gain your trust saying one thing in a meeting, then tell your managers to do the opposite. 
Extremely few managers will have any confidence, ability or cojones to speak up to senior management about injustices and things that are clearly wrong in the organisation - they are rarely willing to take a stand even when they know things are wrong.

Some people are made to feel incapable when the actual reason they can't do something or understand something is because of the lack of solid training in certain areas.

As an organisation they handle change terribly and make very poor spending decisions. They'd rather throw money away hiring expensive contractors and terrible management consultancy firms than actually fix the problems that lead to their high turnover. One of their board members once told us that having such a high turnover was a positive sign for the organisation - and that tells you just about all you need to know about their attitude to how expendable their staff are and how little they care about truly fixing the organisational problems that make staff unhappy.

The job can be very stressful and most people will receive little support for it unless you're lucky enough to have one of the few brilliant managers. You'll be made to find your own way of coping unless you're one of the extremely lucky ones to have a good manager. There are far too many ways that the organisation drains the rewarding feeling of the work you do and as a result, a lot of people burn out, sometimes multiple times before leaving, and there is a very high turnover of staff. When you have teams of roughly six people yet your turnover means more than that are quitting a team each year/two years, you should know you have serious problems and be doing something about it - not just shrugging your shoulders, making excuses and carrying on.

The software used was ancient and was made even worse and less user-friendly when apparently "upgrading" it. Multiple people in charge of upgrading the systems quit during the testing and transition phases because they knew how bad it was but management wouldn't back out of the bad investment they'd made. Just another example of the poor decision-making at higher levels.

review_title: "We do the right thing" - except when it's cheaper or faster to do something else
pros:
Colleagues are generally smart, intelligent and friendly people. There's a free gym, and the canteen is reasonably priced. Benefits are good in terms of health insurance, pension etc but there's not much in the budget for team building or incentives. (Some pod leaders will generally ignore you, and some will drop a voucher for coffee on your desk if you've done something well. This is hit and miss.) There's a lot to learn, and you will get good skills and experience. 

If you like to be busy, there's as much work as you want and you're responsible for seeing it all the way through.
cons:
The call centre department has been eliminated recently, which is probably better for the customer experience but not great for investigators. On any given day, there are usually a couple of "frequent fliers" who call in regularly to scream and shout, and this can be tough to deal with. CCD had training and experience dealing with and filtering out these types of calls. They also took the more emotional first contact calls and the adjudicators could look at the file and make a more impartial decision. Now, that level of screening is gone. 

CCD meant that there were a core of people doing out of hours phone shifts, but now that's been spread across the organisation, and more staff need to work out of hours - too bad if you have other commitments such as childcare pickup and a commute. You'll be expected to work varying hours between 8-8, whereas before a regular flexible working patterns could be agreed with your manager as long as you were present for core hours. 

Working from home is less accessible than it used to be, due to the need to be present for phone shifts or jumping in the queue when busy. Ombudsman Managers (OMs) used to be in specialist areas, but now find themselves writing FDs for areas they have no experience in. We're very exposed to legal challenges and I'm concerned for the integrity of ombudsman's decisions. Luckily, we now have training in how to not give referral rights and conceal the second stage of appeal, so people often take the investigator's word as final, and that's not judicial-review-able. Knowledge clinics aren't available or relied on, because we are too busy to go seek knowledge or do case chats about interesting points. This was where I learned about a lot of the industry guidance available - but there's no trickle down of knowledge from experienced colleagues now, other than "look at the intranet toolkit" which is good in some areas but very basic in others. It's all a bit too guessworky.

review_title: Problems with culture, discrimination and inconsistent management
pros:
I think they are good at recruiting - because they have better staff than they deserve. Most people at the lower levels are nice, and work hard.

I don't think the work is too stressful. The pay and benefits are OK. The work they do (when it is done competently) is a good thing to do. I felt good about the difference I could make for people. I could sometimes feel very proud of my work (but not consistently).
cons:
I think the biggest problem may be that they just don't value management skills. They recruited internally for ombudsman managers, and went almost entirely for ombudsman. They believed that making a decision was something that couldn't be taught, but that people who had never been a manager could immediately be given staff to manage with minimal support. 

It's wildly inconsistent. Rules vary from team to team. It's not bad if you have a good manager, but managers change. I had 3 in 6 months at one point. If you get a bad manager then it can be terrible . 

The organisation cannot admit it is wrong. Which means that when you get a bad manager they will back them up however obviously there is a problem. It's a wider problem, they don't just change rules they deny they have changed them (because that would mean admitting they needed to be improved). Things change constantly but they then act as if they have always been that way - that even applies to guidance they give to financial businesses. You would follow guidance and tell a complainant something, then someone would complain about you and they'd undermine you, say something different and deny you were ever given the original guidance. 

This is particularly bad as they changed so much. Instead of listening to staff (who provided honest and constructive feedback year after year when surveyed, only to see the same mistakes again) they paid huge amounts to consultants who got them to buy whiteboards so teams could "huddle" round them.. Which no one liked or found helpful. They got rid of them as soon as they could. 

I thought their customer service was good. I was genuinely impressed with the thought they would put into, for example, accessibility for disabled consumers. But they never showed any of that compassion to staff. They allowed consumers to be abusive, and did not back staff up. They treated anyone with a disability or health problem terribly. (They are obsessed with standing meetings - I was once at a training even where a heavily pregnant woman and someone with severe back problems nearly got into a fight as they each insisted the other one should take the only chair). They were racist. The number of people taking time of with stress or other induced illness was very high. (The work is not stressful, but feeling undervalued, unsupported and being given no control is). 

You can wait for months for guidance. Their IT systems were so terrible that they were due to bring the new system online for over 1000 staff on a Monday, and at 5pm on the Friday they changed that to less than 10 staff. They paid for outside trainers to train for the new IT system, but did not explain our jobs so they did not know what we would need to do, and could not understand any of our questions. And got them to do it while the software was still in development so by the time it was due to be rolled out it had changed beyond all recognition. And there was no budget or time left to train us in it. Instead of sitting down with expensive trainers for 2 half day sessions in computer rooms we got a 1 hour talk from one of the 10 people who had tried it, talking at double speed to try and give us as much information as possible. 

Instead of having an actual good culture that treats staff with respect they treat people like they are at school. Decorating competitions for Christmas, Easter egg hunts, activities like a school sports day. I was once trying to get my work done while someone was sending out quizzes and activities every hour throughout the day. 

They lost post/cases and I believe they lied to an independent enquiry about this. 

HR is terrible. 

The move to the new investigator system was a disaster. They badly trained people in complicated things while removing specialists to do simple work. Then strangely enough had to move away from this. Having wasted months with the training, misrepresented the jobs, and held complaints up for months while consumers waited. 

Most of the people who work there at the lower level are nice and hardworking (see pros) but when things do go wrong no one steps in. I've seen people in teams just stop speaking to each other while management did nothing. 

They talk in baffling management speak. They train people to use plain English and avoid "jargon" but do not understand that their odd touchy feeling management speak is also a type of jargon. (Their appraisals required showing that you "communicated as a person". )They paid money to get stickers for their doors (in their font, and colours) saying things like "lets PULL together". 

When staff survey results showed people were feeling unmotivated one of my managers made the team have a meeting so we could come up with 5 things that would motivate us. And we couldn't leave until we did. 

They have an exceptionally high staff turnover. Some of that is not their fault - they recruited many young people who could get better jobs with a couple of years experience. But some of it is. I knew one small training intake (8 to 12 people) where none of them lasted a year because they had been recruited on a probationary salary for 6 months, but after 6 months not a single one was taken off probation, or sacked, they were all just kept working at the lower pay being told to meet targets they could not meet (because they had not been trained or supported).

The last staff survey I saw (via another expensive outside consultancy) asked how well people understood what senior management did. The findings gave a whole page to the results of this, because it was "unusual", as it showed that the higher up in the organisation someone was the less they understood what the top staff did. I think this probably sums the place up more than any single other thing - the higher up people were the less they knew until you got people who didn't know what they themselves did.

I worked as an adjudicator in banking and moved over to investigations in 2016. 

I had reservations about the role at first as it is demanding, the shift patterns weren't ideal and it's a stressful environment. 

It took me a while to adapt to the change but I've always been an efficient worker so it wasn't so hard to speed up my process of working. It's actually made me realise how slow adjudicators worked before. I don't believe I comprise on quality, I always learn a case inside out before delivering my view. That's definitely something I could credit the organisation for. I've learnt so much about various different products and I'm proud of this achievement. I don't want to blow my own trumpet but if I'm hitting 6 closures a week than I think other investigators are just as capable. 

I've only been in this job a year and I'm already close to getting my grade 3. This has nothing to do with 'who you know', it's simply achieved from working as hard as I do. 

I don't blame the org or make excuses, I just take on the challenge. Its not rocket science we deal with here. It's products we take out in everyday life. It just takes hardwork and perseverance to succeed. And despite what anyone believes, I take the change as a positive as I know this is only going to develop me even more for better jobs in the future.

Let me make this clear - I love my job. And I think the FOS I joined was a superb example of how to run an organisation and engage your staff. 

As many recent reviews have touched on the organisation is in a state of huge flux. It's clear that the funding model will collapse when PPI is done and dusted, so things have to change. I don't think there's any member of staff who will deny this or say that change isn't essential. 

However there are ways and means of doing this. To get staff on board there have been sinister suggestions that if you don't embrace everything unquestioningly and wholeheartedly then your job is at risk. New roles have been invented ostensibly to get more bang for the company buck. People have been 'persuaded' to apply with little idea of what their new role will entail. Many successful candidates have leap-frogged very capable colleagues with years of experience, all of which costs the organisation more money, not less. 

Those who weren't successful (the vast majority of staff) have now been left in limbo with no idea what their future will hold. And there's no communication from the executive to reassure or explain what even the most short term future will be. Hugely competent staff are left believing their careers at FOS are effectively at an end and as a result the CV factory is in overdrive. Morale is weak. Whispering and backward glances are rife. Even those selected for the Brave New World are nervous and involved purely to secure their job security.

Management and Ombudsmen at the higher levels are grossly overpaid for the jobs they do. Promotion is incestuous and the lack of corporate genetic diversity is glaringly apparent. It's good to promote from within, but sometimes you need a less parochial view. FOS is gasping for the oxygen of some external expertise in turning a business round.
