job_title: Adjudicator Grade III in London, England
pros: I was an adjudicator at the Financial Ombudsman Service for nearly a decade and I have recently left. I loved the people I worked with and I enjoyed the feeling  of making a difference. For me, making a difference was not about how many cases I upheld and how much compensation was paid. It was about balancing out the power difference between consumers and big financial businesses. Even where I did not uphold someone's complaint  I could still help them navigate what are often confusing issues and products.
cons:
The first thing to say is that this is a long post for which I make no apologies. So much has happened and I need to express it not only so I can move on but so people understand exactly what has happened to this organisation that I was at one time, proud to work for.  

The crux of the problem at the service comes from one simple issue. That is that knowledge and skill have somehow been downgraded so that they are now equal to ignorance (a lack of knowledge and skill). In an environment where those things are equal what tends to happen is that those with little or no knowledge and skill for the job of dealing with complaints (either at adjudicator or ombudsman level) tend to get promoted more often that those who do their jobs holding themselves and those around them to the highest standards. This problem is not unique to FOS but it is so much worse in an organisation that makes decisions that can affect peoples financial and even personal well being. 

I am afraid that for a good couple of years, the hard work of adjudicators ombudsman and other staff has been ignored. This has truly turned into a deeply damaging place to be with many people being made to feel that nothing they do is good enough. Many at the FOS are chronically underpaid and in return their targets are increased. If they do not meet these often unrealistic goals, they are bullied out. The way people were measured has changed year on year along with the goalposts. This still persists to this day. The appraisal system is operated behind closed doors and there is no accountability either to staff or for the poor excuse they have for a union (which is little more than a mouth piece for the executive). Essentially people are marked up or down on a scale depending on how the managers in a department feel that day for often nonsensical and spurious reasons. This then influences what pay rise and/or bonus an individual receives. The percentages have been low for years, so much so that people can hop across to the FCA and go from the early £30,000's to somewhere near the early £40,000's. Bearing in mind that these are usually equivalent jobs and that the FOS has chosen to locate itself in Canary Wharf (as does the FCA). 

There have lately been instances where staff have had to get together and go to an external union to protect what are basic employment rights that the executive thought they could trample over. Experienced people have left and are leaving. As with many people my reason for leaving was self preservation. The environment created by the Chief and Senior staff became so toxic that my physical and mental health began to suffer significantly. I am still recovering having left months ago for a job paying a lot less at which I am much happier. Not because it is easier, but because I am now in an environment where people are valued not only by their immediate manager but also the board who are all approachable and accessible. 

I make no secret of the fact that I am bitter, but that does not mean that what I have to say is not worth anything. I am bitter because I gave this employer nearly a decade of my life, I worked really hard and I was committed to doing my bit to make the place a success and help build their reputation. A lot of people do this for their employer and are then made redundant. Not great but they get a pay off. My role as an adjudicator went, but there was no pay off for me because the FOS does not value its staff. There is no doubt that FOS needed to change, but the way this was managed has been brutal, unnecessary and dangerous. 

It was not necessary at all to create new roles or to get rid of specialists. Having ombudsman run teams is actually a really good idea. Why? Because an experienced ombudsman running a team of specialist adjudicators is an incredibly effective way of making sure that the right outcome is quickly reached in the cases they deal with. All of the various areas (banking, PPI, Consumer Credit, Investments etc.) have their own complexities that only someone who works on those complaints all the time will know about. What has happened here is that senior people have taken a look at the easier stuff and decided that anyone can do it. You will always find easy cases in all areas, but a lot of the cases coming through the door require some level of specialism for the right outcome to be reached. 

What we have now is teams of investigators dealing with all case types led by ombudsman managers who are in the same boat as their team. They will know cases they dealt with in their previous roles but that will be about it. The demographic of the people in those roles is mostly younger relatively inexperienced adjudicators/ombudsman or former support staff with no casework experience a brilliant general knowledge but little in depth knowledge.  Most experienced ombudsman and adjudicator simply refused to apply for the new roles and not enough of this experience remains to mitigate the effects of this shift.

The result is a situation that can only damage the reputation of the service by making it more likely that decisions made by staff will be wrong. Not because they are bad at their job, but because they will be made to deal with cases outside of their knowledge. 

When I was there we had links to the new investigation teams to support them in the background and there was a database put together to help them. However, trying to explain a complex issue to someone with no experience in your area is not easy. Also, the database fell victim to the different objectives of those working on it. Some wanted a tone friendly, snappy and formulaic tool whilst others were more focussed on making guidance notes that assumed no knowledge and guided the person through a particular type of case step by step. The result was a series of guidance notes that is mostly worthless if the objective was to help people deal with their cases. The project managers who were simply concerned with 'on-boarding' (what ever that is in plain English) were I suspect, the main beneficiaries of this piece of work.

What about training I hear you ask? Well, having viewed these training materials for myself and spoken to investigators who received it, I can say that it is generalised and wishy-washy.  It is designed to make a person more likely to be good at displaying empathy and persuasiveness rather than reaching the right outcome. That is not to say empathy and persuasiveness are not qualities a good adjudicator/investigator should display but these must been informed by having the right knowledge for the cases being dealt with. This knowledge is I am afraid conspicuous by its absence within the new training materials. There were actually sets of training materials available from all or most areas put together by senior adjudicators and ombudsman for new starters and for those needing to refresh. Hours and Hours of good effective training designed by caseworkers to help other caseworkers. None of this was used. Instead it was condensed and summarised so much that its value was lost. 

It is a virtual impossibility that someone dealing with all case types can build the required knowledge to address a lot of those cases. What is more likely to happen is that they will be good at the ones they see quite often and out of their depth on the rest. With a dwindling supply of support as experienced people leave and not enough experienced people within their own teams, I really do not see how this can work.

They have also closed the Consumer Contact Division. These were the people who answered the phone for new complaints and set them up to be passed to an adjudicator. They were very good at what they did and I cannot stress enough how valuable (and underpaid) they were as part of the service. Now, your call is answered by an Investigator who is also dealing with a caseload of complaints. So in other words, they have limited time for your call and limited time to look at complaints properly in terms of giving each case the time and consideration it deserves

The FOS will release trite statements in the press about how successful all of this has been and how satisfied consumers are with the service. They will also say that times are challenging as they change to meet the evolving needs of consumers and businesses. This is a selective view of the truth at best. There are some posts on here from investigators and ombudsman managers and there are some who I know who are stressed out of their minds. What is also true is that the FOS only uses the positive data. Why? Because having spent about £13m on getting PWC in to design this disaster in a time when they had an annual operating deficit of about £40m per annum – they need this to work. 

The reality is that before PWC came in, we were already making small changes and getting complaints handled in weeks rather than months in a lot of areas. Our consumer and business satisfaction scores were getting very good because it had been realised (perhaps a little belatedly) that getting on the phone and talking to people, showing you are interested in their side of things was the right thing to do for for both businesses and consumers. So what I am saying is that a root and branch restructure was completely unnecessary for the FOS to move forward (rather like the one done in the NHS we are all familiar with). Some smaller and more strategic changes along with getting rid of non jobs for the clique and more accountable spending would have made the place much more effective both in terms of overheads and productivity. 

Another issue was the case fee. A senior member of staff actually said that we could not justify charging more than the £550 case fee because of the climate with the public sector. Firstly, the FOS is very loosely an agency of the treasury. It is definitely not public sector in the same way as the NHS. Secondly, its case fees are paid by the banks and financial institutions with there being allowances for very small organisations. So what difference would it make to a big bank to pay slightly more per case? Very little other than slightly less profit I expect. However, the executive are frightened of the bigger banks and would rather preside over a situation where the bigger banks have under staffed complaints departments and take the cheaper route of using the FOS as an external complaints handling arm.

Whilst all financial business complaints stats are published on the FOS website, nothing was done to stop the practice of bigger financial businesses spreading those complaints over different companies in its group making these companies look better individually. 

You would be forgiven for thinking that as the adjudicator and other roles were affectively abolished, there were redundancies. There were very few. The rest of us were moved to PPI which is now Mass Claims and also handles packaged bank accounts complaints. There was and still is I understand very little actual work for us there as most of the PPI complaints were already completed but just awaiting a court/FCA decision and our other work from our former jobs was slowly siphoned into the new structure. However, they have such little respect for us as people and employees that they effectively put us all on the scrap heap no doubt expecting us to leave and eventually when the bill is almost nothing they will fling a bit of money at the stragglers to get rid of them. 

I think the FOS is in such a state that it has completely lost its way. It is now displaying a severely impaired ability to do the job it was created for. That was to objectively adjudicate financial services complaints ensuring a fair and reasonable outcome. I do not think that the decisions coming out of this organisation can be trusted whilst it insists on ignoring the obvious pitfalls created by this 'new way of working'.

My advice to my former colleagues is to leave. Nothing is worth what this place is doing to you. To new starters, under no circumstances take a job at this place. To consumers and businesses, I would try to sort the complaint out amicably between yourselves. If you have got this far, thank you for reading!

pros:

cons:
I joined the FOS after seeing an online advert for the Investigator role. The role was sold as a chance to work in a small team with heaps of support from management helping consumers resolve their problems with various financial institutions. The whole application and interview process was based around this simple premise. "Fantastic!" I thought - a job where I can actually use my skills to help people who really need someone to listen to them and represent them. 

I joined an organisation in chaos. After barely a month I had realised what a mess the place was in, and what a mistake I had made. 

One of the major issues lies within the operating model. To summarise: the Investigator role is inherently flawed - individuals in this role have far too much to do, and spend too much time answering the phone and carrying out administrative tasks, instead of actually 'investigating' customers' problems. 

On top of this, and the issue that drove me to hand in my resignation, was the pressure I felt on a day to day basis to hit targets. 

Currently, Investigators are expected to close 3.5 cases a week. To 'close' a case means to come to some sort of opinion on the matter, tell the customer, and basically sell your outcome so that 
the customer will agree not to take the matter any further. You can do this by either siding with the customer or the business, and it's no secret that siding with the business is far easier in terms of quickly closing a case. 

I found that managers didn't particularly care about the outcome you had come to - they only cared if you had closed the case.

Investigators are questioned every day by managers how many cases they are planning on 
closing that day/week, and there's a weird culture of what I can only describe as public shaming if your output isn't good enough - management insist on having daily "huddles" where everyone stands around a whiteboard and has to justify their output. 

Investigators therefore cut corners and deliver poor outcomes to customers in order to close as many cases as possible. The threat of being put on a 'performance improvement plan' (if you didn't hit your target) loomed over myself and many of my colleagues, and led to the work being sent out to customers being sub standard, poorly investigated, and just generally a farce. 

I have never worked in an environment so toxic before, with managers breathing down your neck so that you would hit your target.

Members of the public are being done a massive disservice because of this. Many are barely investigating problems and rushing out an 'opinion' - just so that they could demonstrate to management that they were hitting their target. It didn't matter if their 'opinion' was correct, properly researched, or even fair. It just mattered that it was sent out and a figure could be recorded against the manager's name.

Another problem I had was a lack of training and basic understanding of the product area my department dealt with. When I joined, the model was that everyone dealt with every type of financial product. This was then changed to everyone having a specialist area.

My specialist area involved complicated products, often with enormous case files and I would very regularly feel overwhelmed when speaking to customers about these products. I believe I had one very high level introduction to my area, for an hour or two, and that was the end of my formal training. 

That's not to say that there aren't knowledgeable people available to help, but on an average day when you're flitting between answering the helpline, spending ages trying to get an outdated piece of software to do what you want it to, and sending out as many opinions to customers as you need to to keep your managr off your back, it was often the case that there was simply no time to really get to the crux of an issue and fully understand everything that had happened.

Towards the end of my time there I felt like the FOS spent more effort on developing standard approaches to complaints instead of developing staff understanding of the actual technicalities of the products they were investigating.

On top of it all, you have the pointless messages from Senior Management. The Executive Board seem hellbent on ignoring every problem that faces the organisation - particularly the discontent in the workforce. Messages from the top are inconsistent, skirt around the issues facing the organisation, and if I'm honest, are just plain insulting. A strong disconnect exists between the average staff member at the FOS and the Executive Board. Even after the mess that was the Channel 4 Dispatches programme absolutely nothing changed. The response to that was a laughably pointless 'independent' review.

The whole place is ridiculous. The average staff member is overworked and suffering from unnecessary pressure from above. Combine this with poor messages from the Executive Board, no clear plan for the future, and you have yourself a recipe for a very disenfranchised and unhappy workforce. 

A huge injustice is being done to the general public and I am simply outraged at the fact that this organisation is allowed to continue operating as it is.

I was thoroughly disheartened by my experience at the FOS and I am fortunate that I was able to leave when I did - I simply couldn't reconcile the 'work' I was doing at the FOS with my own set of morals.

I will try to be as concise as possible but having worked in HR, I have seen the good, the bad and the ugly. So here it comes.... get your popcorn and read on.

The workforce is totally disengaged, disillusioned and frustrated, this is why: 
1. We have very weak/inapt senior leadership, who all are home-grown. We need to cross-fertilise and bring more commercially minded leaders. Yes you read right – COMMERCIALLY MINDED. Oh I hear the gasps – “but we are not for profit”. Maybe so – but your decisions still need to be commercial and fit for purpose!
2. There is a complete lack of a strategic narrative.  We need a clear, compelling narrative of where we are headed and why. This isn't clear to 99% of the population and I am sorry to say - I work in HR and I am still none the wiser. SIMPLIFY. If Joe Bloggs can’t articulate it in one minute – they have not understood it, meaning you haven’t explained it clearly enough. What I am referring to is called a STRATEGY i.e. a plan of action designed to achieve a long-term or overall aim. Then everything you do on day to day basis needs to flow from that….and your employees need to know the strategy so each cog they spin – they spin in the right direction. SIMPLES. 
3. The employee voice at the Ombudsman is completely ignored, ridiculed or talked away.  This is the very reason why people have taken to Glassdoor to express their inner dialogue. This is linked to very poor communication. Information is drip-fed, orchestrated by internal comms. The FOS was number 25 in the not-for-profit list on the Sunday Times Top 100 Company list in 2013 - can someone please explain how we have got to be one of the worst companies to work for in the UK according to the Telegraph in just 4 years (I should add that FOS was the only non-retail employer on the list). Currently on Glassdoor, we are on par with Poundland – no offence to Poundland but we are a GOVERNEMENT agency. I feel truly ashamed. What are our customers thinking when they come to us? 
4. No integrity or trust. What the leadership tell their employees is not what they actually want in practice. There is a real dissonance in what we say our values are and what actually happens in reality. This translate into some very poor recruitment practices (internally and externally), sink or swim culture overlaid with - if your face fits - great, if not you will be bullied out.
5. Lack of opportunities for involvement, progression or upskilling. I feel like I am deskilling daily at the FOS.  Employees rely know what is expected of them (how many of you have objectives?) we don't feel appreciated (when is the last time someone said well done?) only feedback you get is when you are getting told off for something you probably had no control over in the first place – but someone has to get the blame and it’s your turn so like it or lump it. Furthermore, there is no autonomy in my role and the red tape is second to none. Nobody can make a decision on their own, there are at least 5 approval stages, decision by committee. There is a simple solution here – WHAT is decided by the leadership, but HOW is decided by the people – get your employees involved and listen to what they have to say. 
6. Constant change – because we don’t get it right first time. In HR we have had three HR transformations in three years – all badly executed, poorly planned, poorly communicated, ill-conceived. All down to inability to make decisions, inability to listen to your staff, inability to come up with a plan and stick to it. Speaking more generally to all leadership – there is no shame in standing up and admitting you got something wrong. You would get a lot more trust and respect if you did that. Rather than pretending all is well when there isn’t one thing we can point to that is actually going well at the Ombudsman at the moment.
Which leads me to my conclusion – I thought I was joining the Ombudsman to work for an organisation which prides itself on fairness and doing the right thing.  Perhaps so on paper – not in reality. I have learnt how not to do things: how not to run projects, how not to communicate, how to disengage and disempower employees…I hope someone can turn this tanker around, but it is sinking fast, don't be so arrogant FOS, even the biggest ships sink….I am jumping out to salvage my career. BYE!

review_title: Pick up your dignity on the way out
job_title: Adjudicator Grade III in London, England
pros:
Trying really hard to think of something….. No, nothing springing to mind…..

The café? But I suppose that’s because it’s not run by the Ombudsman…..
cons:
Oh, where to begin?

I suspect that much of what I’ve written will simply be a reiteration of everything that’s gone before on Glassdoor. The debate has been raging for some time and is likely to continue. In truth, this is something of a cathartic experience for me, simply so I can put the whole sorry fiasco of my time at the Ombudsman – and the overuse of hyphens (house style) - behind me. If it helps others to make a more informed choice about applying for one of the new roles, though, then that’s a bonus. Warning – this review contains words of more than two syllables (despite what senior management may think I’m sure you and the general public are clever enough to understand them).

The new way of working does not work. In a world that is increasingly specialised, and in the most complex financial centre in the world, it is not practical, feasible or safe to bypass specialism and technical knowledge in favour of an approach that says everyone can do everything. The banks don’t do it. The insurers don’t do it. The big asset managers don’t do it. The regulators don’t do it. Yet the management at the Ombudsman service seem to think they can circumvent the need for a coherent division of labour based on technical expertise. Is it arrogance or stupidity? Maybe it’s both.

They can’t bypass it. It will end badly when some poor unfortunate investigator who’s just trying to hit their (impossible) target makes the sort of error that gathers traction until there’s an inquiry, a JR, a Parliamentary report uncovering “significant failings and systemic mismanagement”, an embarrassing Treasury Select Committee session for Ms Wayman (or her hapless replacement if she’s jumped ship by then), and a rebranding exercise similar to what the FCA went through in 2012/13.

In the meantime, though, there are thousands of ordinary employees at the FOS no doubt tearing their hair out while being whipped (figuratively) from behind by some just-out-of-university-and-high-on-the-power manager. The atmosphere was toxic when I left, people were bolting out of the door every Friday in their droves, and the management just does not care. If you’re thinking of applying, I really wouldn’t. If you’re there and trying to ride it out, please don’t. You deserve better than to be treated with utter contempt by an employer that values your skills not one iota and doesn’t even have the courtesy to give you meaningful updates on what the next stage of its “plan” is (probably because there is no plan). Value yourself, leave if you can, and pick up your dignity on the way out.

My other big bugbear with the FOS is the total lack of career opportunity and the way the organisation always seems to promote the wrong people. It’s quite an amazing skill in itself. 

With the possibility of one exception, every manager I have had the misfortune to encounter has been a massive disappointment – while relationships may start positively, they eventually show their true colours and it comes like a side-swipe from the blue. They are lazy, self-interested, unprincipled even to vindictiveness, incompetent, crawling and wholly lacking in any substance, intelligence or style. They ride on the back of other people’s hard work, take the credit, take delight in telling far more worthy people that they’re “not ready” for promotion, refuse to support those who deserve to progress – and then get promoted themselves as the final two-fingered salute. Some are now Ombudsman Managers – I pity the poor consumers who will have their complaints incorrectly rejected by them (or incorrectly upheld, which is just as bad because at some point there has to be an embarrassing backtrack), and then have no further recourse to someone who actually knows what they’re doing (except a judge – and who has the time or money?).

I could go on forever but there is simply too much. If it were possible to give the FOS no stars at all then I would. Alas, you can’t have everything in life! So, I’ll end on a little note about the Board, which has been conspicuous by its silence throughout this interesting interlude. Perhaps if we ever went up to the fifteenth floor to visit its fabled haunt – the boardroom – we might find out whether it’s actually on the same planet as the rest of us. Because when all is said and done, how is it possible for (presumably) intelligent, qualified business “experts” to sign off on a plan that makes the entire organisation unfit for purpose in today’s financial world? Maybe the Exec gagged them for being slightly negative about the new way of working.

For those still at the FOS and despairing, there is hope but it needs hard work. Apply, apply, apply for other jobs. Do financial exams – self fund if the FOS has now withdrawn sponsorship. Chase recruiters like your life depends on it – believe it or not they are still interested in the skills FOS employees can offer. It is the only way you will be able to leave, but hopefully when you do it will be for something less archaic, more stimulating and far more rewarding. Your confidence and self-worth will thank you for it.

review_title: Abandon ship is the appropriate phrase
pros:
There has been a lot of bashing FOS and I'm not saying its warranted. But there are good things as well like;

Staff - Most of the staff are good people and try to do their best everyday under difficult circumstances.
Flexible Working - It is nice have a choice on what time I start and therefore finish, especially with balancing family life as well.
Benefits - Some of the benefits are brilliant, I've had occasion to use the medical insurance and without it's unlikely I would've been back to 100% if I didn't have access to it.
Location - An odd one, but it does have quick access to the DLR and main roads which does cut my commute significantly.
cons:
Unfortunately, much of what I want to say is the similar to previous reviews. But, honestly this has been the only open forum that has allowed current and recently former staff to speak honestly.

Targets - Most staff talk about pressure and it's very true that the pressure from the off is to close as many case you can in a week. The target started out as 5 a week, but after the staff survey which was leaked (I will get onto that later) it was reduced to 3.5 a week.  Alot of people might look at this and say it's not that much, but to give a little context behind this, I would pick up a case on something I've never seen, try to understand the issue and give an answer to both the business and the consumer. And hopefully close it then or as quickly as possible. But I have limited knowledge or resources to help or guide me through the nuances of complaints, and even the law itself. So yes there is pressure, and its not just that. Recently the message went around that managers and senior leadership aren't putting pressure on the Investigators and maybe it was self-inflicted, but it's hard to stand by that sentiment when all my direct manager talks about is the number of assessments we've sent out and the number of cases closed.

Knowledge - Lack of knowledge may be more apt here. I can only speak from my experience, but when I moved over as a PPI adjudicator to Investigation I had no training on products themselves. I did get training on our approach to complaints, which may be how we look at complaints. But I had no knowledge to underpin my understanding of how a product works, its aims, and its flaws. I don’t know if this has changed at all, but we’ll see when Dispatches is on as an undercover reporter joined as an Investigator and filmed the whole thing. After being in the Investigator role I can safely say that my knowledge is slightly better, but this is through my own learning and understanding on simple cases. But forget anything like pensions or investments it’s still a bewildering mess to me.

Leadership – unfortunately the biggest problem at the moment. The change program was bought in badly, communication is rubbish and so far nothing has changed. After the disastrous staff survey last summer there was a glimmer of hope change would happen. So far, nothing apart from some lovely committee’s/working groups. Nothing has changed in communication, nothing has changed in transparency and nothing has changed in the lack of direction and leadership by senior management. It’s this lack of change which has led to emails from senior leadership being leaked to the press, and the current inquiry by the Treasury. In fact, watching the answers Caroline Wayman gave made a lot of people angry as it wasn’t the honest truth.

Career path – None whatsoever, though you can get demoted if you don’t answer and close enough cases. Remember that bit earlier about targets, and pressure. Of course the chance of losing you pay rise after working hard, because you haven’t closed enough cases wouldn’t add pressure to say an Investigator with a mortgage and family?

Future outside FOS – None whatsoever, I am actively looking to leave. I can see the ship sinking and I’m trying to get into a lifeboat. Problem is having Financial Ombudsman Service on my CV is actually hindering my search. And this was feedback from an organisation I applied to and was unsuccessful with, oh and they aren’t involved in the financial sector.

Anyone who feels they can convert hop hop ninja abilities into career progression tactics, or anyone who has always dreamed of being a performing animal would be advised to apply here. Adjudicators are more than often ignored and thrown by the wayside if they aren't vocal in what they're doing. Those who demand attention and want to a pat on the back or a treat every time they do a piece of work are the ones who will leap frog through the hoops of progression, leaving the quieter, humbler employees in a fading sound of nauseating self-congratulations.

The job definitely was not as advertised. Presented with an expectation that we could all progress, regardless of how many of us there was, soon turned into a severe game of office politics - where quota's much be reached and boxes must be ticked and those who aren't engaged in this form of sky scraper parliament are sent to the faded green seats at the back.

When applying (and eventually being accepted) for the Ombudsman service I was very attracted to what they stood for, a fair and impartial balance to give consumers a chance and a helping hand in financial disputes. However cliché it may sound, I really thought I was about to make a difference. Only when you have worked with them for some months do you realise how bureaucratic and process bound the service really is. Deviation from the norm is encouraged in theory, but slammed in practice. A wanton disregard for the opinions of those below management is apparent despite being veiled in a pretence of 'we want your views'.

Although senior management are visible much more often that the other reviews will have you believe, there is always a sense or superiority that hums the air. Tones of 'so and so' is coming to the floor today so we must behave. For an organisation that is catching up with its unprecedented and unexpected growth they aren't doing too bad, however. Unfortunately, they're short of the mark and very stuck in the way it was before the growth and seem very tentative about deviating from the original script. However, we can see that a more customer friendly approach is being taken, adopting a Viking as a sort of token mascot paying homage to the terms (ombudsman) Scandinavian routes. review_title: Bleak outlook for those who wish to progress

Decent people.

Career models change so often that progression is exceptionally difficult. When you have reached the top of your ladder, you are forced to move to a longer ladder with no hope of reaching the glass ceiling. Far too many knowledgeable, qualified and hard-working people are wasted at the service jumping through hoops with no real prospect of ever becoming an ombudsman. 

Sadly, I have seen too many instances of unworthy candidates promoted because they spend the majority of their effort looking like they are doing work instead of actually working hard and humble-bragging to the right members of senior management. 

The investigator departments are performance managed by PWC and we are forced into infantile morning huddles in front of whiteboards adorned with colourful mascots and childish glittery stars which disguise the insipid carrot and stick methodology preached by the PWC cheerleaders. People like myself have spent years in law firms, barristers chambers, or in industry and we are now resigned to a performance management style better suited to a primary school. If people are continually treated as children they will start to exhibit childlike behaviour. 

The idea of having investigators as a broad skills work force is not a bad idea in theory, but there should be a select few departments of investigators and the rest of the service should be specialised so people can capitalise upon  their years of niche expertise. If a particular area becomes over-loaded with an influx of cases then the investigators can be mobilised to help bring down the case volumes. However, this current plan of turning everyone into a multi-skilled worker is flawed.

When The Telegraph published last week’s story unveiling the FOS as the second worst place to work in the UK (according to the number of negative Glassdoor reviews), finally the predictions that current and ex-members of staff have been making for months have started to come home to roost.

Thanks to the courage of hundreds of concerned individuals who have taken matters into their own hands since the appalling restructure plans were announced in November 2015, the world is finally starting to take note of the mess the FOS is in. This is the only way that positive, productive change is ever going to be achieved – and the credibility of our job title in the financial world preserved.

From experience, I don’t believe the FOS can ever be changed from within. It is too subservient to Groupthink – the existing layers of management just reinforce the same hackneyed old mindset and uphold the status quo. The organisation is not inclusive in any way, shape or form. Women have little representation in decision-making at the upper echelons of the service; minority colleagues are practically non-existent too. Even down to the personalities it promotes, the FOS only ever values a particular sort of person. If you’re an extrovert you may stand a chance but forget it if you’re an introvert - the quiet and thoughtful are overlooked and criticised for their lack of impact, even if their real contribution is far in excess of the favoured.

This impossible culture can only be changed from the outside. The management are suffering from a severe case of cognitive dissonance - an interesting phenomenon where the more a person or group is criticised the more strongly they will cling to the idea they’re trying to promote. They literally become more convinced that a bad idea is a good one.

Two truths: the Exec is endangering an essential, necessary public service, and the Board is clueless and inept. The whole lot needs to go – along with large numbers of middle and team management that add nothing in the way of expertise or strategic support. The only way they will come under the scrutiny they so thoroughly deserve is if colleagues continue to make such a fuss that the FCA is forced to step in.

So, congratulations for the impact we’ve all had so far – but the work isn’t over. Now you have to keep going – but go forward in the knowledge that you are finally being heard.

review_title: Investigator Role – Get ready for micromanagement, More targets then a dodgy sales company!!!!!
pros: Working with really friendly colleagues who genuinely care about the cases they deal with, great location near Canary Wharf and a nice working environment.
cons:
Where do I begin? 

I joined the  Financial Ombudsman Service as an Investigator in one of the recent intakes late last year in 2017.

The role of the Financial Ombudsman Service and its duty to scrutinise firms conduct within individual cases in its jurisdiction genuinely matters. This is because what we do and how we conclude on a case has a real impact on a person’s life. If we get the wrong outcome the consumer ends up losing out. This is not because individual Investigators aren’t doing their jobs correctly, it’s because there is now a focus on closing a case rather than getting the right outcome on a  case. 

In the Training Academy in the first month it all started off well, 
“we care about your progression” 
"don’t worry about producing to many views or opinions on cases” 
“Your learning so it’s okay take it slowly” 

Still in the Training Academy, then suddenly overnight it changed to: 

“You need to progress your cases” and
 “Why haven’t you taken on new cases” 
“you need to do boring task picker everyday” 
“you don’t have enough converted work (at stage 5)” 
“I’m allocating you 4 new cases to build up your caseload make sure you review promptly”
"Why haven’t you issued your views? …they are sitting in QA awaiting approval…that’s not an excuse, you need to take on more cases”

I have been at the  Financial Ombudsman Service for 5 months now and I really don’t understand why the management and QA are making a huge fuss of the need to use contractions in your work: 

You can’t use: 

they are, they will, they would, they have, they had or I am, I will, I would, I have, I had, that is, 
that will, that would, that has….etc

You must say: 

I'm, I'll, I'd , I've ,I'd, they'd, they've, they'd,……etc

If you miss a few out unconsciously you get marked down, it almost feels the process is designed to undo the good will that exists between employee and employer, almost making you feel you need to be defensive and protect yourself from being targeted and managed out of the organisation. 

Next, is the focus on giving your opinion or view of the case over the phone in every case. There is an almighty push on this, effectively railroading the consumer in to accepting your view because your manager wants you to close the case. 

You no longer volunteer the referral right, you sneak them in to your email hoping the consumer doesn’t notice them so you can close the case and meet your targets. 

It’s a great shame that in the short-sighted drive to make the service more efficient the management have introduced a culture among staff focused on meeting targets rather than getting the right outcome for consumers, effectively diluting what protection the service once offered to its consumers. 

I had read other reviews of the  Financial Ombudsman Service before accepting the Investigator role, I didn’t think it could be as bad as other reviews had indicated, but very sadly it’s all true. 

So, if you are thinking of applying to work at  Financial Ombudsman Service, don’t waste your time look elsewhere because your setting yourself up for a disappointing experience.

review_title: What survived in the darkness is now in the light
pros: The cooked breakfasts and the diverse backgrounds of the staff who mainly do their best.
cons:
1.	I can genuinely say I felt bullied, marginalised, humiliated and helpless at FOS. Why? Because unless you were a ‘favourite’ you were never going to be promoted, no matter how hard you worked and irrespective of how competent you were. I felt that only extreme crawling and flirting with senior colleagues would get you noticed – and I saw too much of that and would never stoop. And, to loosely follow a quote from Ford (he of the Ford Motor Company): “You can have any opinion you want so long as you agree.” This is why so many incompetent people now hold positions far up the pay scale, and this is why an ill thought out restructure has been nodded through. 

2.	I could not stand having to build relationships with complainants, knowing I was going to disappoint them. Some cases – such as fixed rate business loans – were deliberately ‘put to one side’ for years before an approach was formulated. What this really means is that nobody senior wanted to put their name to an approach, leading to a perpetual bottleneck. Having to fob people off – especially when they tell you that they are on the brink of losing their home or that they have nothing to feed their children – is very hard. I felt terrible. Who wouldn’t? But you either tow the official line of you lose your job and your ability to pay rent/mortgage. The Ombudsman talks about being ‘bold and decisive’ although it is anything but.

3.	Some people here talk about how those unhappy with the way things are should just leave. But that is wrong on two counts. The first is that some people genuinely care about levelling the playing field between banks and consumers and the FOS is the one place that (theoretically) can do that. Others, like myself, graduated into the recession. Our intended career paths were destroyed early on and when we saw that the FOS was recruiting we saw this as a potential career opportunity. But, once there, it is extremely hard to leave.  You are not taught much about financial products – only the extreme basics – and most of my knowledge came from financial exams that I decided to take or research on Google.  Now employers have wised up to the fact that investigators deliberately are not taught much, and many have frozen recruitment from the FOS. It is a terrible shame for the staff (especially the non-managers – see below) who do their best. A workman really can blame his/her tools in this case.

4.	Managers are almost always dreadful. I can say with complete sincerity that most of my managers would spend their day whispering to their favourites (and ensuring that the favourites got any of the slim opportunities for progression) or tapping away on their phone. Or simply surfing the internet. They bullied their team with demands for ‘stretch targets’ week on week that invariably meant quality was cut. I became depressed during my time at FOS, and a large part of the reason why was the managers. I can say hand on heart that most of my managers were vindictive because they had nothing else to occupy them and went out of their way to make my life as difficult as possible. I cannot say what here as that would identify me – but the fact that these people are not ‘Ombudsman Managers’ speaks volumes about the very poor state the FOS is now in. 

5.	The targets are not realistic. In fact, the target never stops – even if you get married, it’s Christmas or a relative has died. The target keeps on plodding away in the background, meaning you have to put in insane hours if you dare to take any annual leave. I would often take cases home on weekends and work 10-12 hours a day in the office. Meanwhile managers, who have no target and know nothing about financial products, would saunter in at 10:00 and leave at 16:00.

6.	The restructure has been directed terribly. We once received an email explaining that for the FOS to continue working as it was it would have to charge over £700 per case by way of a case fee to the bank being complained about. Anybody who has gone on the Bank of England inflation calculator can plainly see that had the old case fee (£500) been increased in line with inflation the FOS should be charging banks almost £800 a case. The fact that a ‘new’ £550 case fee was introduced effectively reset the case fee at a lower monetary amount. There are none so blind as those who cannot see.

review_title: Run into the ground by ignorance!
job_title: Adjudicator Grade III in London, England
pros:
Flexible working hours
Good work/life balance
Decent benefits and facilities (PMI, gym, subsidised cafes etc)
cons:
- Pathetic salary for the level of responsibility
- Few career development opportunities
- Numerous examples of nepotism (friends with someone whose Dad is on the exec? Have a promotion. Play football with the right people? Now you're a manager).
- The basis of promotion to managerial roles is entirely wrong and encourages bullying, micro-management, disrespect and arrogance.
- After 5 years I'm still unsure what work managers actually do. They appear to occasionally do some quality checking, deal with complaints about their staff's behaviour and spend the rest of their time having meeting about meetings.
- Numerous layers of pointless bureaucracy. The organisation could half the number of managers and heads of department overnight and it would have little impact on the work.
- Recent changes have lead to a total disregard for technical specialism and knowledge. Senior management seem to think that any Grade 1 adjudicator (now called an investigator) with a years experience can take on any case about any product. This is hopelessly naive and will lead to numerous incorrect outcomes, more claims management companies referring spurious claims to the service, increasing the workload and prevent the people who actually need the service's help from getting it effectively.
- They've spent millions employing an external consultancy firm who have added nothing beyond 'stand around a white board every morning and discuss the work before pledging how much you will get done this week'. This has increased micro-management in an organisation already prone to it. 
- When applying for new management roles one of the questions was 'Tell us how our changes will make the organisation better' (they won't!). It's Orwellian in its propagandist manipulation.
- No oversight of managers. A bad manager will be allowed to carry on despite numerous members of their team going off sick or leaving with mental health issues, due to their behaviour. The manager will never face sanction and anyone raising a grievance will be seen as a 'trouble maker'.
- Anyone who raises any of the above issues will be unable to get promoted to any new role. Only total agreement is valued.
- HR policies seem to be deliberately vindictive and unhelpful

The main problem is the current changes which they have put in place. These were 'trialled' but even before the trials were over it was decided that they'd roll this out across the organisation. Simply put, they expect investigators (usually former adjudicators) and Ombudsman Managers (either former managers or former ombudsman) to be able to take on any case, about any product and reach the correct conclusion. This is a fantasy as the complexity of many of these products means you have to have a baseline of knowledge before you can even attempt them. The new approach works for very basic admin errors and problems with current accounts but when it comes to jurisdictional questions regarding consumer credit agreements, complex mortgage issues and pensions/investments complaints, you need the knowledge or you WILL get the answer wrong. This has been ignored. In addition managers who have never been ombudsman before are expected to write legally binding decisions and be the technical guiding force of their teams when they often have less knowledge than the investigators they are managing. Similarly ombudsman who have never been managers before suddenly have to manage investigators and many of them lack any of the skills necessary to be an effective manager.

In the five years I worked there, I saw the organisation go from a strongly lead, vibrant, exciting place to work, where the people were engaged and cared about the work, to a shambolic parody of its former self, run by an exec completely disconnected from the reality of the situation they're in and peopled by a demoralised, disengaged and thoroughly fed up staff.

Many people like me who saw no benefit in becoming an investigator (why would we want to do a job which involves taking incoming cold calls from the public, working on Saturdays and requires us to do more work with less training when there was no associated pay rise?) are leaving. The brain drain of the Ombudsman's brightest and best has been continuing in earnest for some time and shows no sign of slowing down.

When I joined the service I was very proud of us, my job and our role in society. Our previous CEO had a clear vision, believed in our people, our leaders and our technical expertise. Time and time again we're seeing mistakes made by colleagues who simply don't have the skills, knowledge and experience needed. review_title: trying to fir a square peg into a round hole
pros: Good work life balance. Good benefits (health car, pension and café). Colleagues are actually nice to work with and be around. But that’s about where the pros come to an end! It’s all downhill from here – sorry!
cons:
I'll bullet point my cons as it'll make it easier to follow.

- Substantial apathy from the workforce. All because of structural changes that are continuously (over two years so far) drip fed and they continue to announce new changes making everyone's future even more uncertain. And I thought politicians were bad at answering questions.
- FOS has moved away from prioritising getting the right outcome to wanting to get a case 'resolved' as quickly as possible. 
- Niche/complex casework areas are not valued. Their knowledge and expertise are rapidly leaving the FOS for pastures greener. 
- FOS thinks it can harness these expertise on an internal guidance system but this is never going to work. If, as the FOS says, every case is individual it will be nigh on impossible to draft guidance on most scenarios (without there being information overload) so when the actual people who have the knowledge leave who will provide guidance/help?
- Anecdotal evidence suggests investigators and OM's are overworked and stressed. 
- The employees who have not decided to sell their soul and move over to the 'new world' have actually been forgotten by senior management. We never hear/see them (other than the odd email) around which exacerbates employee apathy. This was not the case before.
- No diversity amongst the FOS board. All older white males/females.
- No diversity amongst top level management. All older white males/females.
- FOS touts itself as a leader in diversity but diversity has a wider range than just employing women. Our external website will demonstrate the lack of diversity in senior roles. 
- Ineffective managers are simply moved around. So the problem is never dealt with.
- It's implicit in the promotions that are handed out that they are given to those special chosen ones.

I’ll leave it at that but this is my honest opinion from what I see and feel – and it’s not uncommon. I’ve been here at FOS for four years or so and I did enjoy the first two years of my career. I’ve learnt a lot and the job was challenging, but sadly not anymore. Off to pastures greener for me and that definitely doesn’t mean I’ll become an investigator.

review_title: 3 Years since I left and it seems nothing has changed
pros:
The benefits were good.

The hours were decent (but then whats the point in having more time at home if your just going to be sitting there of an evening, absolutely dreading going into work the next day).

There were some very good people on the front line (my fellow grunts so to speak)
cons:
I did not realise about the Glassdoor reviews until A former colleague of mine (from the service) posted a link to the Select Committee interrogation of CW on Facebook. 

I have to say, having read all of the recent reviews, I can relate to almost every one of them. 3 years on, the picture they paint accurately reflects the many reasons why I left in 2015.

Although only in my late 20's at the time, I had nearly a decade of experience across corporate companies, so I knew what to expect when I arrived at the Ombudsman.....Except I didn't, i really didn't. I foolishly presumed it would be more of the same, your typical office environment (just a bit more professional if anything). In Truth, nothing could of prepared me for the environment in which I was drafted into. 

My manager had just been promoted into the position, having been at the Ombudsman herself for only 6 months, we were her first team (formed from scratch).  Herself, in her early 20's, she didn't have a clue about managing people, and having been there for less than six months, didn't really know too much about the job she was overseeing either.  But she had an eerily close relationship with the head of the department , which obviously, could just be a coincidence. However premature & fast tracked promotions for people in certain circles were endemic within the organisation at the time. Consequently, her lack of experience meant that she was always trying to 'act' as to how she perceived a manager to be, instead of actually being a manager. It was like she was a robot reading from a textbook on how to manage, and trying to implement the text word for word. Instead of using initiative, intuition etc. you know, using human traits and adapting to resolve any given scenario. She was trying to shoehorn textbook answers out of her management book into every situation.

Onto the quality checks. Micro management was rife, with your manager and various appointed sub-ordinates, checking your work several times a week. Problem with this is, that they all had different standards, different interpretations of the "Ombudsman way". This inconsistency meant that the goalposts were always being changed, week on week. I would literally get marked down (and fail my QC) one week. So I would change my approach accordingly, to only be marked down the following week, by someone else, for doing what I'd been told to do only a week prior. 

This causes massive problems as you are judged as an adjudicator by the success rate of your Quality checks, indeed fail 3 QC's and your on a P.I.P.

The last straw for me, was when I failed a QC of one of my phone calls with a stakeholder, My manager failed it because I hesitated when the stakeholder questioned our ability to service there complaint. Well at the time, I actually agreed with stakeholder, and lieing doesn't come natural to me, so I did hesitate before I lied to them and assured the stakeholder that we are going to give there complaint the investigation it deserved. But even so, to fail a call for a brief pause before answering someone is tyrannical (knowing that three fails and your in trouble)

I left the Ombudsman a shadow of the person that walked through the door. My time there consisted of always being whipped, brow beaten, stripped of my identity and told that I am not good enough. Like a horse, i'd almost been 'broken' into submission.  Luckily I had just about enough confidence left to get out, I've now been working for the same company since I left. I'm an accountant for a global top four industry leader. I love it here, and they appreciate me; more money, great environment, more responsibility, a lot more autonomy, achievable ladder to climb. I would encourage those left, to get out as soon as they can. The outside world is waiting for you, and is waiting to offer you a better lot than you are currently getting.

pros:

Great stepping stone. If a graduate wishes to have a career in compliance and is not sure how to get their foot in the door, the ombudsman is a great place to do it. No previous financial knowledge is required to become an adjudicator - you just need to demonstrate good communication, organisational and customer service skills.
Technical knowledge developed on the job is great. Its pretty scary when you first start but you eventually find your way.

They will then accuse us of being in the pockets of the banks. Let me make this clear - we have no motivation to reject complaints unfairly. We do not salivate at the prospect of telling you that you aren't going to get any more money. We do not want to have to defend our position to you for an hour or more on the phone.

Adjudicators do the bulk of the organisation's work but are not rewarded particularly well in terms of pay and opportunites for progression. The salary is good if you are just out of uni but if you're not then its pretty rubbish. Saying this, however, it is not so much of a problem if you think strategically. They keep their eye on the figures, customer service and deal with service complaints, however, without technical knowledge, they are limited in the help they can give adjudicators. Current team sizes could easily be increased 50%, reducing the number of team managers. There would then be a bit more money to go around for the rest of us.

FOS has a relatively small number of truly technical experts - ie. adjudicators that have been in the job for more than 10 years. Unfortunately, in the battle for promotion, these individuals can be sidelined to make way for the younger generation. You therefore often have relatively inexperienced people mentoring/checking work etc instead of those best placed to do this. I think FOS needs to appreciate, and make more use of, those that have the most knowledge. Creating technical specialist roles may help to do this.

pros:
-Flexi time
-Pension
-Benefits such as holiday, dental, etc
-The vast majority of consumer consultants, consultants, adjudicators and generally lovely people who I have worked with.
cons:
Up until November 2015, I would have rated the Ombudsman service as one of the best places to work. Indeed, it was one of the best places to work in the Times polls for several years. Work is generally dependent on demand and nobody minded that because we were all capable of managing our workloads and finding things to work that needed work.

Over the last year the entire organisation has completely changed its structure. There's no trade secrets here - the Ombudsman service's complaints will be worked in the main by "Investigators" and they will be managed by "Ombudsman Managers" in the future. Investigators effectively replace the "Adjudicator" role, brought in to assist the Ombudsmen that were originally writing the decisions, but with the advent of the multi million PPI complaints, needed the assistance of adjudicators to cope with the caseload.

Adjudicators in the main specialise in different fields, such as PPI, Banking and Credit, and so on and so forth and all the various areas have sub divisions. Nothing you don't know from the website or can ask the press office about. Standard stuff.

Investigators do not specialise and are in fact encouraged not to by "sharing knowledge" within "pods" - which are groups of investigators led by an Ombudsman manager. They are expected to share their knowledge and experience of different case types and financial products around in order to "make the service relevant and sustainable" for the future.

That would work, except the pods aren't really balanced by the knowledge base that the adjudicators have. The first recruitment process looked haphazard and ignored previous skills, relying more on interview technique to justify reapplying for a similar, if not identical, job with a different wage structure.

The management and the press office have over the last year spent an ordinate amount of time undermining the majority of the adjudicators by effectively putting a clock on their careers. Many of the best adjudicators have already left and more will follow.

The service seems to need to shrink in size for various reasons, and management are taking some startling steps to address this. There are several adjudicators from my area looking to leave as a result: I myself am considering my future and looking to leave at the earliest opportunity.

The shame of this all, as we have discussed, is that the core values of the service which we have upheld over a number of years were good: sharing knowledge, doing what we say we will, do the right thing and similar, all contributing to the best of our customer service. We weren't a perfect organisation - who is? But we all bought into the message and worked for one another, and our consumers (both ordinary people and businesses, and their representatives).

Two colleagues of mine have been managed out and I fear that I am in a similar position. Having never so much as had a service complaint raised against me in all of my four years at the service, with awards for customer service and having trained others, I find myself in the unenviable position of having to justify my quality of work in the most pressured and most extraordinary ways possible. My manager has seen more of me during work hours than my desk has and the constant negativity towards my work has taken its toll. This came during a time of great upheaval in my personal life and the more pressure he placed on me, the more I felt there was a incredible lack of pastoral care and the humanity you normally associate with us as a service. 

It feels very much that we can go to the nth degree for the consumers and if it's in the "business needs" but when you need support from the company to get things back on track they don't want to know and would rather find ways of getting you to quit, whether it is being passive aggressive unpleasant for a long period, or undermining you with meetings, PIPs (performance improvement plans - which are meant to be about improving but in reality are a way of throwing you under a very large bus).

One such colleague of mine is going through an even more horrendous time at home with a family member seriously ill and effectively acting as a carer. His manager is aware of this but hasn't reported this to the line manager, who is of the opinion that he can't be trusted with work. 

He's one of the most dedicated and hard working individuals that I know, and the quality of his work over a three week period on a "new work stream" wasn't of the highest standard (but wasn't of any risk to the business either) and that justified, apparently, putting him on a PIP and furthering his anxieties and depression. He's not alone and I have seen several managers - who will say to your face "we're not managing you out - but" do this to their adjudicators.

The management structure as a whole at the Ombudsman service is broken. Adjudicators with no managerial qualifications or experience were hired to take on teams. Many of these are now doing further damage to the organisation by demotivating their teams to try and thin out the organisation. The attrition rate is awful and it's not surprising given what is going on behind closed doors.

I wouldn't recommend joining the Ombudsman service - I would advise you go and try the FCA, for which a number of former colleagues have joined and are flourishing in their new roles - and wondering why they stayed so long at the service in the first place.

As for me, I am considering my future and whether I can justify the additional stress to convince management to keep me on. 

I always put our consumers first and if I hand in my notice soon, I can do so with my head held high because I have always wanted to uphold the decent values of the service, and to help people as best I could wherever they needed it.

I used to be proud to work at the Financial Ombudsman Service. But now it is an omnishambles.

pros:
Good benefits. Pay is average. Very few will ever become wealthy from working here. But few don’t work here for pay, they work here for the people, good work life balance and job satisfaction.  

Work can be very challenging but also very fulfilling.

Good ad-hoc working from home.

Cafeteria with cheap and cheerful choices.

A decent  gym which is available to employees 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
There are a lot of people that work here who sincerely care about what they do, care about getting things right for both sides, are happy to help their colleagues and truly live the values.  But it is a vastly different story with the entire executive team and many senior managers.
cons:
This used to be a place where we took pride in what we did. It's with sadness that we've found ourselves in this current position. The thoughts and advice on FoS as an employer which I express here have been echoed from many across all levels of seniority. 
 
Exec's no longer ask how we feel in a way that gives us the security that we won't be punished or judged for expressing ourselves in a constructive manner. We used to do an anonymous staff survey every year which they recently pulled, it was done by an external company. Instead, now they use an internal method and ask very different questions that tell them only what they want to hear. They refer to this as a "pulse check". They also say exec drop in sessions are to "get to the heart" with how we are feeling with things. When your staff are being lied to, manipulated, taken advantage of, even bullied when asking valid questions, who is going to feel comfortable speaking out? Not many can risk that. It's too easy to be identified and who wants to be singled out? 

This is why many of us have resorted to Glass Door to make our feelings known. This was picked up by FT Advisor in an article online. You will need to search for it, it was published, 27 July 2016, and titled "Fears FoS restructure ‘could harm quality of decisions’" The journalist obviously has an inside source. But our organisation's response? "it's not based on fact" I am afraid it very much is. 

FoS has an ethos, values we commit to. For much of the time that I've worked here (between 5-10 years) one of the greatest things about it is that it did not feel like some of the meaningless values many organisations claim of themselves. It felt real, it was imbedded in the culture, our values mattered. It was our identity and we were proud to embrace it. Of course, no place is perfect and there are always exceptions, yet it still truly felt genuine and sincere from a majority of the people who work here.  It is what made us proud to work here and what previously placed our organisation in the Sunday Times top places to work for.

Last year changes in structure were announced. Change can scary, but we understood why. Many were excited about these changes. It meant working in a better way which would benefit our consumers. As it has developed over the last year, it has been nothing but an utter calamity. One disappointment and shock after another. Our best people have been devalued, demoralised and discarded. 
 
The internal recruitment being carried out is not so that our most talented were chosen on either merit or even on the basis of their achievements. Instead, it's been very difficult for many of us to make much sense of it at all. It's been poorly managed and far from transparent. People were denied roles for nonsensical, unreasonable and even offensive reasons. "We didn't realise who you were, we had never heard of you, you are doing really well but just do it a bit longer, you don't understand the challenges because you are too enthusiastic, there was just someone better than you this time, you are too confident"

We are worried about the future of the organisation and the impact that this could have on decisions. Like a sales team whose main goal is profit for themselves, FoS as an organisation have become about how quickly we can provide an answer regardless about how it is done or whether it is right or wrong. What is happening now internally could destroy us as an organisation. Managers are being put into positions with little technical knowledge. Ombudsmen are now line managers and many of them lack in people skills. Investigators will be providing answers about products they haven't been trained in. We are already seeing cases come back that are a mess. Many are jumping ship before it gets worse because we see what's coming, and it is coming. We also don't want to be part of a culture where speed is valued over doing the right thing in the right way for both parties. 

Sadly, the majority of people applying for the new roles are doing so because they have to now, not because they are on board with this vision anymore. Many will be in roles they didn't want and felt forced into. The CEO, Caroline Wayman, and her team have now lost the chance at retaining many of the most knowledgable and passionate people. The loyalties of the best and the brightest of FoS have shifted.

They do not care about our point of view, when we have challenged them constructively we are shot down. They don't respect their employees anymore, and many of us are beginning to think perhaps they never did, perhaps we were the fools. Either way, we no longer recognise the culture are in anymore. People come to us for help, we give them answers that can have a severe impact on their lives. We must do the right thing regardless of the time it takes. However, if FoS can't be open, honest, communicate like people, care about the world around them in regards to their own staff, how can they be expected to do it with those who need our help. 
 
The CEO, Caroline Wyman, will no doubt continue to gloss over this feedback as she has been, only addressing these feelings of ours when she is forced to. But always with the same manner as if she were waving a pesky fly from her face. 

There is a recent article written by our ex-CEO, Ms Natalie Ceeney that has been making the rounds. We wish our leaders here would take heed to. It's hard to imagine it wasn't written in light of what is happening here. 

It is in Linked In, it's called "Don't Believe Your Own Hype" published 19 July, 2016.

I would have posted links but they are not allowed in reviews.

pros: When I first joined the Service I felt that I was making a positive difference to people's lives, and that I had a rewarding career path with ample potential for personal growth. I knew that I was on the right side, always trying to do the right thing. But...
cons:
...in recent years the organisation has taken a series of cataclysmic lurches in an alarmingly negative direction, and it has become a profoundly demoralising place to work. Pretty much everyone I know is trying to get out, and all for the same reasons.

Years ago, subject matter experts were seen as a valuable commodity - yet today everyone is expected to be broadly competent in all subjects and expert in none. Consequently, many cases end up being handled by people without the requisite specialist knowledge. This results in under-trained investigators making best guesses in complex and nuanced situations, and the subsequent decisions are often inconsistent or plain wrong. Quality checks seems to have been abandoned in some areas, with predictable consequences - it's pot luck whether or not cases are routed to someone competent. I feel deeply sorry for the front line investigators, who are expected to deal with consumers and businesses often about very technical things, but without even the most basic of required training.

The executive team itself is profoundly inadequate and broadly mistrusted. The CEO is pushing through an extremely disruptive and unpopular programme of reforms in which all existing roles are being discarded and replaced with roles that look remarkably similar but with very little flexibility or career progression. This exercise is also being used as an excuse to clean out huge numbers of staff who do not find a suitable place for themselves in the new order. Consequently we are losing our most competent and valuable employees at an alarming rate and morale is lower than most of us ever thought possible. 

The ill-thought through changes dreamt up by the executive are dishonestly promoted as successful. There is a conspicuous lack of MI to show that the new changes work any better  and those on the ground who have the misfortune of implementing them widely acknowledge this new regime to be an unutterable disaster. The CEO has surrounded herself with a clique of fawning yes-men (who, incidentally, were told that they needed to adjust their moral compasses by the previous CEO!). The changes are short-sighted and are being implemented purely to make the executive look good in the short-term. 

The rhetoric around the need for change is that we need to be financially sustainable which few disagree with. But it is clear that the case fee has been kept unduly low - a very modest increase of a few pounds would solve our financial woes, but there seems no appetite for this at the board level. Perhaps due to political pressure? Also telling is the lack of minutes of the board meetings - none have been published since March 2016. Have they stopped being published or have the board simply lost interest?

For some years FOS had Adjudicators as the bread and butter of the organistion. So they released the 'Investigator' role with a whole new structure and pay grades to boot that were higher than Adjudicator.

Sounds like progress right? Wrong. When re-structuring they decided to do away with many of our specialist teams and just pool us together so we can solve 'anything'. This doesn't work for a myriad of reasons that should be plainly obvious. Also they decided it would be smart to do away with our administration teams so we now have to setup cases, do all the admin around them and investigate, hit unreachable targets and learn a huge number of specialist areas that we've had little to no training on. Genius.

In addition to that the new Ombudsman Manager role to manage said Investigators has primarily been filled with people who have little to no experience as a manager. Most are previous technical experts in respective areas who have no idea of our systems, processes and most crucially how to manage. 80% of the time we're told it's all a 'new way of working' (anyone from FOS reading this will likely chuckle at that phrase, as they know it covers all manner of sin), and want us to do things that simply do not make sense for us, the businesses or consumers.

An Investigator's job is to balance the job of an Administrator, Adjudicator, technical lead and self-manage whilst being constantly bombarded with 'new' processes and management quangos that drive everyone into the ground. You may think that writing such a review is because i've been slighted in my role and I have some form of grievance against FOS. I am actually doing quite well because for now i'm simply cruising along playing the game (whilst internally hating every idiotic second of it). No, it's actually because of the disgraceful conduct in which the management are treating my colleagues, and systematically bringing down an organisation I was once very proud to work for.

You won't find a single Investigator within our organisation that doesn't loathe their job and have a multitude of negative things to say about our 'new ways of working'. Good luck getting an inteligible response to a complaint, the person you're dealing with has in truth probably only dealt with a handful, if at all, of those types of complaints before and won't be aware of basics right up to law on the subject.

Our CEO is non-existent, nor the YES men around her that have risen through the ranks for no apparent reason.
