Avoid this organisation like the plague.

review_title: Used to be good to work for but not any more
pros: Once was a great company to work for, felt you did a good job and were rewarded appropriately.
cons:
Now, staff are like lab rats on tread mills, stressed out worried about their futures, feeling that the company couldn't care less as it’s made clear there's always plenty of people looking for jobs (although, from what I've seen, most new people leave for other jobs at the first opportunity and within a relatively short period of time, just using this place as a stepping stone). 
Most staff are on edge, feeling underappreciated and definitely not listened to, no longer able to do a good job because of the need to follow a one size fits all process and deal with cases as fast as possible and worse hurtling towards being a glorified call centre (and we all know how popular they are). You might think well isn't processing a complaint quickly what you should be doing any way, well yes, but, it shouldn't be on the basis of a process that relentlessly moves forward with unreasonable performance targets as the driving force. 
As the obsession with the financial bottom line takes a grip all the platitudes about caring for staff, work life balance is just that, and hollow to boot. The latest thing for staff, because we are so well thought of, is we now have to apply to do roles which essentially we are already doing. The roles have been retitled but the work is pretty much the same (we aren't supposed to spot that), the clear intention behind this is to get rid of people, have less staff doing more, in truth a cost cutting exercise. In my opinion in the long term this is short sighted, they want us to be a glorified call centre having a little bit of knowledge on all subjects. How that's going to help consumers remains to be seen.  At the moment we do still have set areas of expertise so banking is dealt with by people who specialise in banking complaints, investments by skilled people who understand and can talk sensibly on the subject, insurance is so broad motor, household, pet, medical, travel, legal and so on all at the moment dealt with by people focussed on those areas. 
The new way of working will be to take phone calls on all complaints with the expectation that you provide the consumer with a good experience, of course the moment you show it's an area you aren't familiar with or show a lack of confidence and you fumble and stumble around trying to be reassuring and build a rapport, it’s no likely to go down well. 
As for the business of having to apply for one of the 'new' roles (laughingly also called opportunities) it seems to be a wholly unnecessary exercise when you take into account the amount of information from appraisals, daily, weekly, monthly observation by management etc that’s held on all members of staff. The process of bringing out the new roles has a been a typically (for this place) ridiculously protracted one and caused a great deal of unnecessary anxiety among staff. Further it's been made clear that if you aren't successful applying for one of the ‘new’ roles you can either leave or be consigned to PPI ultimately to be made redundant or, as is no doubt hoped for, become so disenchanted that you just leave. 
And to top it all, just for a laugh, if you’re 'lucky' enough to be offered one of the new jobs you then have to accept the new salary maximum range. And just to make you feel that you really matter, if you’re already earning in excess of the ‘new’ maximum, although you can still receive annual increases for the moment, in two years’ time a correction will be applied and your salary will arbitrarily be reduced to fit in with the maximum so a substantial pay cut looms, and that’s what’s thought to be a decent way to treat staff. How that is fair or reasonable is beyond me and it's clearly designed to hit the older longer serving staff at all levels who have misguidedly given loyal service believing this was a decent company to work for. I wish we had a Union.

review_title: This place is perfect if you are ambitionless, have no goals and do not want to better yourself
job_title: IT Service Desk in London, England
pros:
- Discounted Canteen
- Good benefits like pension scheme and private health care, holiday insurance
- Free onsite Gym
- Great location
- People in general are polite and easy to talk to
cons:
Where to begin. A step in the wrong direction in terms of career progression.

I worked in IT Service Desk and I use that term loosely because I am having a hard time justifying doing any actual IT work there. If you are a grad and have interest in computers and love fixing things, do not apply to work in IT here. This is a dead end job - you will not learn any valuable transferable skills here. This whole company is just a glorified call centre and what ever department you work in most of your job will be just talking on the phone. You are not encouraged to learn anything more then whats required to do your job. There are a couple of in-house applications you will be supporting - skills which are useless if you decide to go and work somewhere else. If you want to know anything more advanced, sorry, not in your job description.

If you like solving problems and really finding the root of the issue, I tell you now you are in for a massive disappointment. You're not here to use your brain, you're just a keyboard monkey who types the problem down and passes it into the abyss not really knowing if it's going to get resolved by someone and in what time. If you're familiar with a ticketing system, you know when a problem arrives you have certain amount of time to resolve it depending on its severity. Here this means nothing. You will be told quality of service is the holy grail of the IT department, but this is coming from the people with 0 experience in doing the actual job. For the last couple of months of my stay all I did was apologise to people who called us for help because their problems were not resolved for weeks on end. Several factors contribute to this appalling lack of service:

- People are not being trained:
++Absolute lack of any structured training. If you want to know something go and find out for yourself. When the department is being run by non technical people, they are not in the best position to advise what you need to know so your only option is to find experienced people who have been around for a while. Even then everyone has their own way of doing things so you will either learn the bad habits or the good habits. In my time there, not one person was trained in the same way.
If you think you're going to a big organisation where technology is bleeding edge and you're going to learn cool stuff like Migration, Imaging, or even just installing and building stuff - forget about it! This job doesn't even require you to hold a BTEC diploma in computing. What you will be doing is burning CDs, ripping CDs, releasing emails, changing passwords, and telling people to restart things - a lot - and there isn't even a path you can follow to progress. If you're tech savvy you may have a chance of moving up to second line. If you're not, well then good luck to you. 

- There is no team atmosphere
++ In every meeting we are constantly being reminded that we need to work as a team bla bla bla. Unfortunately the nature of the job makes this impossible. It is so heavily stat driven that you end up only caring about meeting your own targets. When you pick up someone else' job you will find they do it in a different way to you and you get into an argument that this was not done right or there's lack of information. Blame culture is very strong here and its even worse between teams.

- Recruitment of quality people and not being able to hold on to good people
++ The management and HR do not seem to care about your technical abilities, it is all about your manners over the phone. If you're polite enough and can type at a reasonable rate, congratulations you're hired. Do you know what a computer is? irrelevant. Yes, this is the state of an IT department. Some of the people calling us about the problem even tell us how to resolve it only because we have access to a particular system and they don't. Simply embarrassing. There is a Catch 22 situation here - it is very difficult to recruit the type of person that will fit this role. If you get someone interested in IT, they will leave within 6 months of being here. If you get someone who knows nothing about computers, they will increase the work load for everyone else. What you want is someone who has been doing service desk all their life and does not want to be anything else.
There's also laziness problem, I have never worked with so many half-arsed people. Simple, 2 clicks issues are being passed around like a hot potato and it's only too easy to call in sick and get away with it. Some people have more sick days then I have holidays - impossible to have a fully functioning team week in week out

- The only thing lower then the moral in the team is the Mariana Trench
++ Everyone hates their job. The fact of the mater is this job is not rewarding, not intriguing and everyone is being treated like a child. There are rules about where one can eat lunch. There are rules when you can and can't go to the toilet. The job is so repetitive that you might as well work on a conveyor belt packing boxes all day long. There is no praise for doing a job well but a telling off reaches you faster then lightning when you make a mistake. There is a difference about being told off by your mentor who showed you how to do it but you still messed up and being told off by someone who hasn't been in your shoes even for a day. This is like a pilot being told by a passenger how to fly a plane

- Management seems to be oblivious to the state of affairs
++ No one stays here for a long time and no one seems to be asking any questions why so many people are leaving. Good people who have ambitions and want a rewarding career are running for the hills after a few months of 'doing time'. As long as the stats are showing the right numbers everything is fine. Team meetings are a one way discussion, you're told whats going to happen next and if you have any suggestions for improvement make a wish and it may come true. You feel like you're just a number and your job is not to provide input - your job is to carry out orders.



This place needs a serious shake up. In any role, doesn't matter what the job is, if the people are not happy you will not get much productivity from them. A very simple statement that is overlooked time and time again.

cons: Once upon a time, the organisation sold this dream of fairness, transparency and strong values - and it was almost believable. I give Caroline her dues and it’s almost unfair she has to pick up the slack with the wrong doings of her peers.  But it’s secretly known among the vast number of trusted and loyal employees, that her execs will rather pour poison in her ear or covertly betray her vision than be honest to the realities of the work place. Some say it’s desperate self-preservation of their positions, but I call it spineless adults who’ve forgotten there’s honour and respect in being humble about their mistakes. pros: Superficially a nice enough place to turn up to because the team people are alright, the place is clean and the benefits are not too bad.
cons:
The Financial Ombudsman Service, the place where no clue meets miserable unhappy staff.

Does ever moving goal posts, senior management who don’t know and don’t listen, some lower managers treading all over you and using you as their catalyst for self promotion sound like what you’re after? How about a ‘trust us with your future!’ approach when really anyone with one IQ point can see their leaders actually have no clue what they’re doing but can see they’re being fobbed off or lied to? Well then, the Financial Ombudsman Service may be for you. Or maybe not…

The people are ok and the benefits aren’t bad. But, unless you want to work in a place where grade promotion is inconsistent and getting harder, or non-existent if you're in certain areas, senior management have no leadership skills and don't care what you think and you’re just expected to do as you’re told, then don’t consider working here. It’s horrible and getting worse.

I’m not prone to whining and I don’t dislike my job. But, I hate where I work and who I work for. It has now got to the point where those of us who don’t want to have our contracts changed to our detriment to fit a new model which is already flawed and failing are going to start being bullied out of our jobs, whether it be sooner or later. Bullied, of course, in a slow and subtle way, not outright.

Changes ahead. They’re been mentioned. All of the negativity detailed - and I’ve read most of it - is all true. I’d say moral was at an all time low, but that would be bringing it up to that level. The one or two positive reviews have clearly been written by people who’ve been there less than 18 months and are just out of uni. Or the HR department to make out it isn’t so bad. There is no joy in working day to day on a bigger level other than your own direct team.

Years ago, Natalie Ceeney turned up. She turned what was an organisation set up to deal with complaints into a corporation which began to think it was almost part of the social services. And that’s when it started to go down hill. It became more about PR and looking good to the outside world and being touchy feely with consumers - ‘how can we help? (right up there with ‘do you want fries with that’), ‘tell us your problems!’, ‘we can help you!’ all of which kind of fade out when the end response to the complaint is simply - ‘sorry, your complaint hasn’t been made in time…’

If you hear the Financial Ombudsman Service use the word ‘customer’, hear - consumer or general public. That’s really what they mean. It’s not really about businesses, they’ll just do as they’re told. Again, the management like to say ‘people, not process’ when dealing with complaints, but it’s the absolute opposite when it comes to the people dealing with those complaints. At that point, it's process before people. Simply put, they don’t have any interest in the staff or their opinions.

Senior management like to think, or rather say, that they listen but they don’t. They’re simply not interested.If you ask a 'tough' question they'll either ignore it or defer the answer. They won't and don't take responsibility for what they're doing or saying.

Caroline Wayman has her heard buried in the sand around her and simply just ignores what’s going on because she’s sowing the corporate rubbish. She doesn’t care that people are unmotivated, scared and worried about their jobs. You can only judge someone by their actions and not what they say. She says a lot, does nothing.

Besides, why would she and her cronies listen anyway, they know everything already and believe their own carefully manipulated stats and ignore the fact that their new model just won’t - and already doesn’t - work on a blanket approach. Their ‘answer in room’ concept is more like ‘the answer is in the building…somewhere, if you know who to ask. But don’t worry too much about finding it, because we need to do things quickly, not properly.’

For a bit longer, you have specialist teams dealing with complaints. Soon, under ‘the new plan’, it’ll be sloppy rubbish being churned out to meet the targets by people who don't understand what it is they're selling (saying and/or writing). It is already, I’ve seen it. You can't effectively answer a person's query or complaint if you don't first understand that complaint.

Interestingly, the people/grunts who have been around a while can see the reality of the situation. Many of the newer people - the ones almost straight out of uni, wide eyed and quick to swallow whatever it is they’re told - are happy to be sheep. Or the new investigators, same thing really.

You have investigators who are inexperienced being led by managers and ombudsman, some of whom bend over backwards to uphold complaints. Fair anyone? Nope, but it happens anyway. If you get an MP involved, surprise! The complaint will either be in jurisdiction or upheld. It’s about pandering to the public. Do you like us? Aww, go on, like us… Give us good feedback so we can tell everyone how great and ‘relevant’ we are…

Many of the new investigators aren’t experienced in dealing with complaints and some haven’t even dealt with them before. Ok, everyone has to start somewhere. But, basically, many people just applied for these roles because it gave them an instant pay increase. Or, like now, they’re scared they’ll lose their jobs or end up in PPI. However, the ‘one size fits all’ approach to dealing with complaints will, of course, work regardless of these little (read - big) concerns.

The Ombudsman Service is happy for its experienced people to leave. Why would they not; they have answers, experience but cost more than someone in their first job out of education. In fact, they’re more or less advocating this by shoving anyone who doesn’t apply for the new format into PPI - the [almost] end of the road. You’re either with us or not, and if you’re not, then well, we don’t care about you. 

PPI is dull, boring and has a shelf life. With the annual staff turnover recently being in the 20% plus area, it won’t be long before ‘the undesirables’ leave of their own accord. Saves paying them redundancy then as this is cheaper and means more money for the old boys club to spend on their own fat salaries and pay rises.

And, I can’t not mention appraisals.

Do you want to be appraised fairly? If you do, don’t work at the Ombudsman Service.

The new appraisal system is just like the new way of working - sloppy, under thought and, of course not reflective of the truth.

We now have three grades to be judged on - [effectively] underperforming, adequate or simply amazing. 

The first two are self explanatory. The third one basically means in order to get that grade you have to be doing so much other stuff as you’re almost doing two people’s work. So, most people won’t get it. 

The obvious flaw here is that you can be just scraping by as adequate or doing really well but not enough to get the top grade and you’ll get the same result, and pay rise. Fair? Of course not. Why bother working hard or making extra effort when the guy next to you doing just above what they need to will get the same reward? But it does make it easier to bundle everyone together and keep the pay rises down to a minimum. Also, if you do manage to stay for a long time, you’ll get a lower pay rise than the people who have just started. Again, fair anyone? Nothing like rewarding experienced long standing staff.

So are you interested in working at the Financial Ombudsman Service? 

Would anyone let a person who can’t see drive them down the road? No. But that’s exactly what is going on at the Financial Ombudsman Service. The staff all know it, but the management just ignore it. The fact that there has been a massive increase of reviews on this site - which they hate as they can’t control it or happily brush it aside - and the tone of these reviews, says volumes. Read them all. If a place really isn’t so bad, why have so many people said the same thing about it being a shambles? Why are the reviews increasing so much?

So, if you’re a business or a person on the street, expect a slap-dash approach to your complaint going forward, because that’s what’s coming to you in 2017 and beyond. There’s a car crash on the horizon folks, and it’s getting nearer all the time. Don’t say you weren’t warned.

review_title: Why no changes to senior management team?
pros: Non-salary benefits are good. If you're desperate for a job, these are worth looking at. But look for work elsewhere first.
cons:
In a previous review concerns were expressed that there is no accountability, at senior level, for the mess the Financial Ombudsman Service has become. By senior level I mean board & executive level, directors of casework and head of levels.  This applies across all departments in the  organisation including  the inept Stakeholder Team.

There have been strong indicators for several years that the ability of senior management has been lacking. The evidence and indicators were clear. But what I’d like to say is that there is no recognition for the adjudicators and ombudsmen who, mostly, feel real value in what they do and are working hard to prop up a failing model. There certainly isn’t any slacking in the ‘transition’ area. The adjudicators are on full targets and a lot are also fielding calls from investigators about the basics of all products and doing other things like sifting cases, which the new world hasn’t factored in. All of this, despite being told that we’re not seen as part of the organisation’s future.

I genuinely mean no disrespect to the investigators - they’ve been put into a situation that isn’t their fault - but someone with no Portfolio Management experience handling complaints from serious and often very knowledgeable investors isn’t going to work. My colleagues in pensions say the same thing - even the lesser experienced pensions adjudicators need help from the more senior adjudicators. So how did the management expect investigators to get up to speed within two years? It certainly hasn’t worked. 

It’s the same in my area. They’ve put people into 70/30 pods where they’ll be specialising (sorry, focussing on certain products) for 30% of their time. But if they’re doing other cases for 70% of the time, how will they be able to provide swift answers to more complex cases. I can do things quickly, but that’s because I deal with the same issues everyday.

The new model doesn’t have the capacity (I heard it is behind in its productivity and that another department-customer help is having to take on the postal complaints as the new model hasn’t got the staff). My friends who became investigators tell me that they are under extreme pressure and that, despite what we are told by managers, they are finding shortcuts to closing cases. For example the right to have an ombudsman reconsider the case is conveniently missed out by some investigators, making it look like their answer is the final answer. That’s because a referral takes more time and doesn’t result in a closure because of the time it takes to get a decision.

There’s another point. The original model envisaged the highly paid team manager (now known as an ombudsman manager) to look at and provide final decisions for cases where their team were unable to resolve the matter. This isn’t happening as they (mostly) spend more time on managing the team and not being an ‘ombudsman’.

So returning to my original point. Despite having people who are capable and willing to carry on ‘helping our customers’ where they have an expertise, the service seems intent on moving us to deal with short term lending or PPI or making us apply for voluntary redundancy.  The decision making skills defy belief and they are so out of touch with what is actually happening.

And finally, additional complaints are only being resolved because of incentive schemes. Currently an additional few weeks target will be paid at a time and a half. But in the ten weeks before the end of the financial year we were paid double time to try and get us near the figures needed to be able to justify the new model. None of that was in the annual report!!! The service didn’t hit the overall target (they blamed PPI uncertainty again), but we got paid nicely for some easy work - which the investigation model should (as the leadership team announced two or more years ago) have been more than capable of doing. Again, this isn’t the fault of the individual investigators, it’s the situation they’ve been put into. 

To those who are happy in the investigator role, I’m pleased for you. I really am because it does suit some people. But I hear more negativity than positivity from the area about what the senior management (above OL) expect. And please don’t refer to adjudicators as slackers or moaners. We’re not! We’re trying to do a similar job to you (just without the phones and setting up of cases). We’ve got full targets and are providing support. Next time you or a colleague calls one of the helplines, imagine what it will be like for you/them when we aren’t there. Because the way things are currently being planned by the executive, come April we won’t be!

A call centre that can resolve any financial complaint with a chat is pie in the sky stuff but that's what 'they' (head of/senior/lead/director I've no idea who doe what) envisage. 

There are people who've spent years becoming experts in product one area  but somehow youthful enthusiasm is going to rank above that and anyone can deal with hundreds of complex products and know all the workings of them. The idea is that you can find someone who has the answers but how does that help the customer who wants help from someone who at least sounds like they know what they're talking about?

People appreciate there needs to be some change but the complaints aren't going to get easier. The experienced staff have historically been undervalued but now they're being tossed aside completely. they're simply unwanted and don't fit any longer and the new roles are a way to weed out anyone who's too old or too well paid, the salary cap will see to that.

The way organisation expects to work in future is simply unrealistic in view of the types of issues it deals with. The current investigators are already findings themselves out of their depth on such a range of products but dare not speak up. Sooner or later they'll realise that the old system wasn't that far off the mark and could have been refined but how much damage will be done by then when customers who want to speak to experts get someone who can do nothing more than listen and cross their fingers they'll be able to deal with the problem eventually.

There is a lot of double speak at this organisation with senior staff saying all the right things and pretending they have 'values' but they don't. They have made a number of very poor ill thought out decisions and ran with them with no accountability. The appetite to change is due to poor financial decisions of the past - largely due to a top heavy structure where there are loads of senior staff who do nothing or other poor decisions e.g. even though the organisations was moving offices in 2014 - that same year it paid hundreds of thousands to upgrade the board room to make it look like a hipster cafe. The board table was designer and each of the chairs were also individually made by designers and that alone was rumored to have cost in the 10's of thousands. No idea what happened to all this but it wasn't moved over to the new building. 

The most frustrating thing when i was there was that that was masqueraded as helping progression made it much harder for people to progress and also reduced all the overall salaries for anyone new coming into the organisation. Alongside this, the senior staff (largely who used to be the old football team) kept getting promoted and inventing new jobs for themselves. For example, one of their mates was alleged to be promoting attractive females who flirted (or allegedly more) with him and when this all came out he was promoted to an ombudsman - despite not being all that bright. 

It's a massive shame because the idea of the organisation was good but now it just isn't fit for purpose and the real losers are the lower level staff who work there and also the consumers that turn to it for help. The organisation simply doesn't have the specialist knowledge it used to because people are leaving or because new changes expect staff to deal with complaints from all areas rather than specialist areas. E.g. the same adjudicators (or investigators) and ombudsman will look at consumer credit, pension and insurance complaints. It took me about 2 years before i got the hang of consumer credit alone. 

Unless you have no other options i wouldn't work here. It's a bad place to work and is not good for external progression like it used to be as the industry knows that the quality of staff has plummeted. You won't be treated with any level of respect.

cons:
Energy and enthusiasm is rapidly diminished in the face of the Borg - these are the exec/senior management who make it clear very quickly via their Vogon managers that any criticism of their style or approach is not to be tolerated. Resistance is futile, it's assimilation into the collective or you go out the airlock either voluntarily or are pushed. 

Never seen such a large communications department for the size of organisation, nor one given such a disproportionate amount of perceived power and run like a fiefdom, which is appropriate given the chosen Avatar for comms is a Viking (and we all know what Vikings are associated with!). Their modus operandi is to dumb everything down to the language of about a 9 year old, patronising not only their customers but their own staff as well [Don't make it your first job or you will never learn the language of business or management]. Their graphics look like rejects from Play-school. They pump out initiatives that appear randomly as if they have not gone through any proper organisational development planning and process, with HR looking on Borg-like. As someone said recently, 'it's like the tail is wagging the dog'.

Don't expect a strategy. There isn't one, which is astonishing and reflects its lack of commercial edge. Hence this is a rudderless craft. That has massive implications for performance - which appears below par - with the direction of travel changing depending on which way the Borg determines the wind blows. There is a nod to a set of values and behaviours that differ markedly between the said and the done, e.g. 'listen', which seems to only apply to customers not to a core principle for the Borg with its crew. If they did they may realise there are some really excellent people out there with excellent ideas but they may be challenging to manage BECAUSE they have brains and ideas. e.g 'fair', which certainly does not seem to apply to many of the selection and promotion processes, nor to how people are treated who might dare to ask, 'why?' or may have a passion for excellence and know what it can look like because they have brought in their expertise from other organisations that DO have that passion.

Don't expect one culture. The way that staff are managed and work in one area of the business is not necessarily the same as everywhere else. Some parts have a strong ex-banking culture so it's very fixed hours and particular dress code (for example) whilst other areas may be less formal/rigid in approach.

pros: Still some flexibility left in terms of working from home and working hours. Some great managers and some really knowledgeable ombudsmen.
cons:
The great ombudsmen are being replaced by ones with no experience. Utterly demotivated staff, even amongst those successful in getting new jobs. Bullying is rife at all levels. The correct outcome on cases is now irrelevant in the drive to be ADR compliant and to deliver swift outcomes. 

There are few workable cases left in PPI, yet the board recently saw fit to advertise for 25 new PPI ombudsmen, gave the job to 37, even though there aren't enough cases to justify it. Or to even justify 25 appointments. Millions of pounds have been spent employing contractors while there isn't enough work to go round permanent staff. The board and public accounts committee seem uninterested in the waste of money because the organisation is barely accountable to anyone.

Communication is non-existent, occasionally directors visit to talk down to the staff, invite questions and then report anyone asking difficult questions to their manager.

Existing ombudsman manager colleagues admit they don't know enough about the products they're being asked to make decisions on. The board seems either not to know this or not to care. 

Many staff are being asked to accept worse contracts for less money, unless you're a member of the executive.

All the staff understood the need for change, many welcomed it. Everybody knew that the organisation would need to be smaller once PPI ended. But this was not shown to work in the trials, isn't working now, was delivered in a way that needlessly alienated a loyal and experienced workforce and is in danger of destroying the service. People will get quick, wrong answers from inexperienced staff who don't know what they're doing.

The current rumours circulating are that the organisation is going to reduce the amount of redundancy pay in order to save money when the inevitable redundancies come. If so, the executive and board should be ashamed of themselves. It would demonstrate yet again that they absolutely do not care about their hard-working staff. While just a rumour, I could well believe they would dump staff on the scrapheap with as little redundancy pay as possible to balance the books while pouring money down the drain on contractors and change consultants.
